Results for the healthy group are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (social-comparative judgments of close vs. non-close others) in healthy adult participants (N=20, ages within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, univariate voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Target × Breadth interaction, Positive > Negative, Close Other > Non-Close Other) analyzed in SPM and provides peak coordinates and cluster statistics for activation maps. Although ROI-based correction is emphasized for a priori regions, the manuscript presents whole-brain group-level task-evoked contrasts (including an exploratory whole-brain caudate cluster) that are clearly reported for the healthy sample. The study is empirical, not a review, and does not report only connectivity or ROI-only results. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain univariate task activation in healthy adults.

Although the study used fMRI during a social joint-attention task in healthy adults (n=24, age 20–34), all reported imaging inferences were made using small-volume correction (SVC) within four a priori ROIs. The manuscript does not present or report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level, voxelwise task-activation map (or whole-brain corrected results) for the healthy/control group; figures are shown for illustration at uncorrected thresholds but inferences rely on ROI SVC. Because the review’s inclusion criterion requires at least one group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked map generalizable to healthy adults, and this paper reports only ROI/SVC-corrected results, it fails the whole-brain evidence requirement and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception of others’ head turns/social attention) in healthy adults (participants aged 22–38; healthy volunteer group reported separately). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate whole-brain analyses (Whole-Brain Analysis and Univariate Analysis sections) with FWE-corrected coordinates and maps described for the healthy group. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain, task-evoked fMRI evidence in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (movie viewing) investigating social-emotional processing (empathy/social interaction). The authors report group-level, voxelwise intersubject-correlation (ISC) maps and voxelwise regressions linking valence and arousal to ISC (whole-brain statistical maps/localizations reported across cortex and subcortex). Although the analysis uses ISC rather than a conventional task>baseline GLM, it provides whole-brain, univariate voxelwise group-level effects that are generalizable to healthy adults and clearly reported. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only without whole-brain maps, or non-healthy-only sample) are violated. Thus the paper meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI evidence of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (n=20) and an fMRI task of social-related visual perspective-taking, the paper does not report an univariate, whole-brain task-evoked statistical map explicitly for the healthy/control group. Second-level analyses were ROI-restricted to prefrontal regions and reported condition effects across participants and group×condition interactions, with exploratory seed-based connectivity results. No unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group voxelwise activation map (reported as a healthy-group main effect or within-group contrast generalizable to healthy adults) is provided. Therefore it fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=304, ages 18–22) using an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma (a social task). The paper reports group-level, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., CD>CC) with whole-brain analyses and FWE-corrected cluster results (in addition to ROI analyses). Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults within the specified age range. The study is task-based (not resting-state or connectivity-only) and provides whole-brain statistical maps/analyses, meeting all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social processing (face emotion discrimination), involving healthy adult participants (mean age ~31, range within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (one-sample t-tests of EE vs baseline and EE vs EI across all participants and flexible factorial group analyses) with tables of coordinates and cluster results; results for healthy participants are reported and generalizable (not limited to a narrow subgroup). Analyses are not ROI-only, nor limited to connectivity or resting-state methods. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked maps reported) and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is a single-case fMRI report (n=1, one 22-year-old female). Although whole-brain analyses and coordinates are reported, the study does not present any group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map generalizable to a healthy adult group. Inclusion criteria require at least one group of healthy adult participants with group-level whole-brain results; that criterion is not met. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (social sharing/affiliation) in healthy adult participants (female, age 20–33). The paper reports group-level, univariate task-evoked whole-brain analyses (second-level full-factorial ANOVA) and presents whole-brain corrected activations (e.g., precuneus, DLPFC, bilateral amygdala) in addition to ROI results in VS/OFC. The sample includes healthy adults and fMRI results are reported for the healthy group separately (n=26 for fMRI analyses). The study is empirical, task-based, and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-emotional processing (guilt), a social-related construct involving perception/understanding of self and others. Participants are healthy adults (scanned N=20, mean age 25.7, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., guilt memories vs neutral memories; thresholded at p<0.001 with cluster extent) and provides coordinates and figures of activations, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses include whole-brain results (in addition to SVC), and results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not non-empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

While the study uses task-based fMRI of self/other social processing and includes a healthy control group, the available full-text/abstract only describes between-group effects and group main effects (hyperactivation in BPD; greater activation in controls) and does not clearly report an unmasked, whole-brain, within-group task activation map for the healthy/control group. The inclusion criteria require a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked map clearly identified as coming from the healthy adults. Because that criterion cannot be confirmed from the provided text, the study must be excluded.

The study uses task-based fMRI with social-cognition paradigms (empathic and forgivability judgments). It includes a healthy adult comparison group (n=14; mean age 30.5) scanned and reported separately. Group-level whole-brain, univariate SPM results for the healthy/control group are described (within-group activation maps, coordinates, and tables/figures for empathic and forgivability judgments). Although a clinical group is also included, healthy-group whole-brain task activations are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/understanding of others’ actions and the force they apply during action observation). The sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=12; mean age 26, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task-evoked analyses using SPM12 (GLM with parametric modulation and SUIT cerebellar analysis), including voxelwise thresholds, conjunctions, and tables/figures of activation—i.e., whole-brain healthy-group task maps. The study is empirical and not limited to ROI-only, resting-state, or connectivity-only results, and does not present only between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This fMRI study investigates mentalizing (Theory-of-Mind) during comprehension of literary narratives—directly addressing social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Participants are healthy adults (N=18, ages 18–27). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (Mentalizing vs Action and Action vs Mentalizing), with corrected voxelwise thresholds and reported clusters (aMPFC, STG, PCC), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is empirical, task-based fMRI in healthy adults and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of person evaluation (social perception of others) with healthy adult participants (N=20 males, ages 19–31). The paper reports both ROI and an exploratory whole-brain voxelwise analysis (group-level ANOVA) with coordinates and a table of activations (Table 1) from healthy participants, satisfying the requirement for an univariate whole-brain task-evoked map generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This study uses task-based fMRI of social processing (approachability social-judgment task). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=33, mean age 36.5, within the 17–65 range) and reports group-level, within-group task contrasts. Whole-brain task-evoked activations are described across groups and within-group analyses are reported (main text and supplementary tables/figures s3–s6), with cluster-level FWE-corrected results and voxelwise FWE checks; an amygdala SVC is also reported but whole-brain cluster results are present. Therefore the paper provides univariate, group-level whole-brain task activation maps/results identifiable as coming from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults, fulfilling the review’s inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of empathy/social cognition in healthy adults (n=23, ages 19–34). The task is social-related (perception and understanding of others’ affective states), and the paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., Pain > No Pain for similar and dissimilar targets) analyzed with SPM and reported in tables/figures. Whole-brain results (functional segregation contrasts) and localization are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. The study also includes connectivity analyses, but these are supplementary to whole-brain task activations. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, includes healthy adult group, reports univariate whole-brain task maps). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This study used task-based fMRI during a social decision-making paradigm (the ultimatum game) in healthy adult participants (male, ages 23–28). It reports group-level whole-brain analyses: an offline cross-subject whole-brain SVM classification with voxelwise weight maps and permutation-derived p-values (discriminating volumes reported, e.g., bilateral LPFC, occipital cortex, AI/right AI, vmPFC, ventral striatum, OFC, pSTS). These results constitute group-level, voxelwise evidence generalizable across healthy subjects (leave-one-subject-out cross-validation and reported discriminative volumes/p-values). The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and includes healthy adults within the required age range. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (Narrative Experiment: n=41, ages 18–37; separate localizer group n=14). Tasks probe social cognition (empathy/theory-of-mind, processing others’ emotional suffering and false beliefs), clearly within the review’s social-related constructs. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (SnPM random-effects; corrected p<0.05) with contrasts such as PP>PPC and EP>EPC, and provides peak coordinates and tables of activation (Table 3 and figures). It also reports ROI analyses but not exclusively; whole-brain results are primary and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, participants within 17–65 range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses task fMRI during face processing (a social-related construct) and includes healthy control subjects, it is a single-case study focused on a clinical patient (ASD + developmental prosopagnosia). The abstract and available full-text information emphasize patient vs control differences and functional connectivity results; there is no clear statement that the paper reports a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group that is unmasked and generalizable to healthy adults. The results appear to rely on between-group contrasts and connectivity analyses rather than providing an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect. Therefore it fails the required 'whole-brain evidence' inclusion criterion.

Although the study uses task fMRI with social stimuli (face perception) and includes a healthy adult sample (ages 18–37), the paper’s reported whole-brain voxelwise results are framed as continuous age-regression and developmental effects across a mixed-age sample rather than as a clear group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy adult group alone. The inclusion criteria require at least one clearly identified healthy/adult group-level whole-brain task-evoked map (e.g., adult faces>objects). Because no explicit adult-only whole-brain contrast map or unmasked adult within-group statistical map is reported in the provided full text (results focus on age effects and mixed-sample analyses), the study does not meet the requirement for healthy-group whole-brain evidence and therefore should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=23; age 21–37) investigating social gaze effects on action control (a social-related task). Data were acquired at 3T and analyzed with SPM using whole-brain, voxelwise univariate GLM contrasts at the group level (main effects and interactions reported, cluster- and voxel-thresholding described). Results include whole-brain activation maps and tables/coordinates (e.g., Table 1, SPM figures), not limited to ROI or connectivity analyses. The healthy-control group is reported separately and generalizable to adults 17–65. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical, out-of-range sample) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults addressing social processing.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study probing empathy/social cognition (perception/understanding of others) using visual social stimuli (human and animal suffering). Sample: 60 healthy adults (ages 18–60) reported separately; groups are healthy omnivores/vegetarians/vegans. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise, univariate task contrasts (within-group and between-group) with MNI coordinates and FWE-corrected results, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, resting-state, or non-empirical paper. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of emotional facial expressions) in healthy adult humans (N=23, ages 24–34). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate task contrasts and significance maps (random-effects group analysis, cluster-corrected maps, stereotactic coordinates and figures/tables provided) for the healthy adult sample. Results for humans are reported separately from monkey data. The task clearly targets social communication/perception of others. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This fMRI study used a social-related task (dynamic happy and fearful facial expression processing), which fits social perception/understanding of others. The sample includes a healthy control group of young adults (mean age ~22, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts for both the familial risk (FR) and control groups (thresholded Z>2.3, cluster-corrected p=0.05), with figures and tables showing control-group activation/deactivation clusters. Although a familial-risk group is included, results for the healthy control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study also includes ROI and PPI analyses, but these are supplementary to the whole-brain task maps. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

Study uses task-based fMRI of social interaction perception in healthy adults (N=21, ages 18–35). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate whole-brain analyses used to create ROIs (group-constrained whole-brain contrasts for localizers: interaction>scrambled, bodies>objects, faces>objects, mentalizing>pain), and also reports whole-brain searchlight analyses. Although main reported results focus on ROI/MVPA classification, the presence of group-level univariate whole-brain localizer contrasts (clearly described in Methods) satisfies the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from a healthy adult sample. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in healthy adults.

This study includes a healthy adult control group (n=13; mean age ~34–36, within 17–65) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation maps for the healthy/control group (SELF > lexical, OTHER > lexical, conjunction, SELF > OTHER) with coordinate tables and corrected cluster thresholds. The task probes social-related processing (self- and other-evaluation of personality traits), fitting constructs of Perception/Understanding of Self and Others. Healthy-group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is empirical fMRI task-based (not ROI-only or resting-state) and provides voxelwise activation contrasts for the control group, so it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition specifically probing perception/understanding of self (general and contextual self-judgments). Sample: 24 healthy adult participants (native Japanese and Caucasian-American university students; mean ages 21–24), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain random-effects analyses and provides tables of coordinates and figures (e.g., Tables III–V, whole-brain regression and interaction contrasts, and corrected MPFC result), not ROI-only results. Healthy-group effects are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, no clinical-only sample). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (empathy for others’ pain). Sample: 36 healthy adult participants (mean age ~21), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (painful vs non-painful) with multiple-comparison correction (FDR) and tables/figures of activations, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain univariate task-evoked maps for the healthy group are clearly presented and generalizable. No exclusion criteria apply (not resting-state only, not ROI-only, healthy adults reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this is an fMRI study of social (facial emotion) processing and includes a healthy adult control group (n=9, mean age 37), the paper reports only between-group contrasts (VCFS < controls and VCFS > controls; Table 1) rather than an unmasked, whole‑brain, group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group (e.g., main effect or within‑group on>off contrast for controls). The inclusion criteria require at least one clearly reported whole‑brain univariate task-evoked map from the healthy adult group. Because qualifying healthy-group whole-brain results are not provided (results shown are group differences/contrasts), this study does not meet the whole‑brain evidence criterion and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults that used a social task (viewing faces of real-world social network members) probing social cognition and valuation. The sample consists of community/college adult participants (within 17–65). The paper reports group-level task-evoked neural activity in affective valuation and social-cognition systems using whole-brain analyses (not limited to ROI-only or resting-state/ connectivity-only approaches) and describes results generalizable to the healthy group. Independent functional localizers and whole-brain contrasts/coordinates are reported in the main text and supporting information. No exclusion criteria are violated (not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain univariate task fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=13, right-handed males, age range 19–36 within 17–65). It uses a social cognitive task (theory of mind and empathy cartoon task) and reports group-level, univariate whole-brain random-effects analyses (contrasts: ‘ToM’–‘Physical1’, ‘Empathy’–‘Physical2’, conjunctions and interactions) with voxelwise thresholding and tables of Talairach coordinates (Table 2). Analyses were conducted in SPM2 and results are presented as whole-brain activation maps/coordinate tables rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only approaches. Healthy-group effects are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=16, ages 18–25) using a social competitive task (matching-pennies) involving human and non-human agents. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate GLM results with second-level random-effects analyses (voxelwise threshold p<.001 and cluster-level FWE correction p<.05), including tables of peak coordinates and figures. The task probes perception/understanding of others and mentalizing, fitting the review constructs. No ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state-only limitations apply, and participant ages fall within 17–65. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (empathy, Theory of Mind, self–other differentiation) in healthy adult participants (male, age range 21–40). The authors report group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (random-effects GLM) with voxelwise results, cluster thresholds, coordinate tables and figures describing activations for the healthy sample. The task is clearly social-related (inferring others’ internal states) and the reported results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes healthy adults 17–65, reports whole-brain group maps). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (13 right-handed males, mean age 28.2), using a social-related perceptual task (biological motion / perception of others' actions). The paper provides group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (canonical vs scrambled biological motion) with corrected statistical maps and tables of MNI coordinates and cluster sizes (p<0.05, corrected). Although connectivity (seed regression and DCM) is also reported, the study clearly includes univariate whole-brain task activation results for a healthy adult group that are generalizable to the population of interest. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

Although the study includes a healthy control group (n=33) and uses fMRI with social-cognitive tasks (Theory of Mind), it does not report a group-level, whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group. Results focus on patient versus control contrasts (patients>controls) and patient regression analyses; the paper explicitly states that controls did not show any areas of greater activation than patients, but does not present univariate whole‑brain healthy-group task effects (maps or coordinate tables) that are generalizable to healthy adults. Analyses were restricted using ROI small-volume correction, and the reported results are framed mainly as between-group contrasts and patient-focused effects. Therefore the manuscript fails the inclusion criterion requiring a clearly identified, whole-brain, univariate healthy-group task activation map.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=13, mean age 27.2) that used a social-related task (passive observation of realistic movie clips depicting social interactions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (relational vs. alone; relational vs. rest) with corrected significance, tables of activation coordinates, and figures. Analyses are univariate and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes adult healthy sample within 17–65, and provides whole-brain task activation maps). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (directors and matchers; ages 18–33) examining collaborative vs. individual learning and retrieval in a communicative/social task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Collaborative > Individual, Individual > Arbitrary) with cluster-level multiple-comparison correction and tables/figures of coordinates. Results for the healthy sample are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor limited to between-group contrasts. Thus it satisfies all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n≈302 initially; final groups of 18–22-year-olds), using a social-interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) to probe social cognition. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses (GLM contrasts for CC and CD outcomes, cluster-thresholded Z maps) and presents whole-brain activation clusters and coordinates for treatment-by-methylation effects as well as condition contrasts. Participants are within the eligible adult age range (18–22). The study is empirical, reports task-evoked whole-brain results for healthy subjects (separately by sex and genotype), and provides tables/figures of whole-brain findings. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and group-level whole-brain univariate results).

This is an empirical fMRI study probing a social cognitive process (theory-of-mind/false-belief reasoning). It includes healthy adult participants: a large MIT reference group (n=462, ages 18–69) and a Caltech control group (n=18, ages 21–46), providing healthy adult data within the target age range (Caltech group within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (Belief > Photo) for the healthy reference groups (voxelwise and cluster-corrected results are presented and used as benchmarks), not only ROI or connectivity results. The study thus meets the inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain univariate maps). No exclusion criteria are violated.

The study reports a task-based fMRI experiment (observation of others’ risk-taking vs safe actions) that targets social-related processing (action perception/understanding of others). The sample consists of healthy adult participants aged 18–22 (N=25), which falls within the 17–65 inclusion range and reports results for the healthy group. Group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (risk-taking vs. safe contrasts) are reported with SPM maps, cluster results, and coordinates (p<0.001 uncorrected, k≥10), not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This fMRI study used a social-related task (passive viewing of facial emotions) relevant to perception/understanding of others. It included a healthy adult control group (n=27; mean age ~40, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (within-group activation maps for controls are described and listed in the Supplementary Material) and presents whole-brain between- and within-group results (cluster-corrected). The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and provides healthy-group whole-brain activation generalizable to adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

The study uses fMRI during an irony-comprehension (social cognition) task and includes a healthy adult control group, so it addresses the review topic. However, the full text as provided does not clearly report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map explicitly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Results emphasize combined/main effects in “study participants” and between-group contrasts (controls>schizophrenia) and correlations; no unmasked, within-healthy-group whole-brain task map is clearly described or tabulated in this paper excerpt. Because the review exclusion criterion disallows studies that report only between-group contrasts without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task effect, this paper must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (action understanding/mentalizing) in healthy adults (N≈19, ages 18–32). The task manipulates social inference goals (why/how/what/observe) during action observation and reports group-level, task-evoked univariate analyses (random-effects ANOVA) with voxelwise results and peak coordinates. Although primary ROI/mask-based correction was applied, the paper explicitly states that whole-brain results and mask details are provided in the Supplemental Methods, and reported contrasts are generalizable to the healthy control sample rather than limited to an ROI or connectivity analysis. The study is empirical, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and reports whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy participants. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social interaction (joint action, leading/following, mutuality) in healthy adult participants (n=18; mean age 40.4, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate task contrasts (multiple contrasts, FDR-corrected maps, cluster thresholds) with Talairach coordinates and tables of activations. The task probes social-cognitive constructs (perception/understanding of others, social reward, mentalizing) and is not ROI-only or connectivity-only. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social processing (legal decision-making: responsibility and punishment, which involve perception/understanding of others and social cognition). Sample includes healthy adult participants (final analyzed N=20; ages 18–45). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts and regressions (whole-brain contrasts and tables of peak coordinates, FDR-corrected) for the healthy participant group across multiple task conditions. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and not a between-group-only contrast. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (N=34; mean age 22.2), using a naturalistic movie-viewing task that probes perception and understanding of others. The authors report group-level analyses including whole-brain voxelwise reverse-correlation maps and statistical parametric maps (χ2 and corrected thresholds) identifying regions (DMPFC, TPJ, temporal poles) responsive to social interactions. Thus: (1) task is social-related (mentalizing/social interaction); (2) sample is healthy adults within age range; (3) whole-brain, group-level task-evoked voxelwise results are reported and described. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state, not clinical-only). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports an fMRI task of emotional sentence attribution (EMO) versus grammatical classification (GRAM), a social cognition task involving emotion processing and theory-of-mind/reasoning about others. The sample includes a healthy adult group (n=25, age range mean 33.1) reported separately alongside a clinical group. Whole-brain, voxelwise group-level analyses are reported with FWE correction (p<0.05) for task effects, group effects, and task×group interactions. The paper explicitly states that healthy controls significantly activated the medial prefrontal cortex during the emotion attribution task (and presents whole-brain statistical maps/peaks), satisfying the requirement for a healthy-group, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked map. The task and reported contrasts are clearly social-related and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study uses task-based fMRI (naturalistic movie viewing of a socially engaging Toy Story clip) probing social-cognitive processing. It includes a healthy adult group (reported separately; final N=21 adults) within the 17–65 age range. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level statistical maps: within-group inter-subject correlation (inter-SC) maps for the Adult group (with peak coordinates and cluster-corrected results), which are univariate, voxel/node-wise statistical tests generalizable to the healthy adult group. Analyses are not limited to ROI or seed-based connectivity and are not resting-state only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (affective Theory of Mind) in healthy adults (N=21 analyzed, mean age ≈23.7, right-handed), within the 17–65 range. The manuscript reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (e.g., 3rdppA > 1stppV localizer and EFE > no EFE contrasts) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster statistics (Tables 1–3) and whole-brain results described in the text and figures. Although ROI and PPI analyses are also present, they supplement—rather than replace—the whole-brain univariate maps. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain task fMRI of social-related processing and should be included.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (right-handed heterosexual males, age 20–32) performing social/affiliation-related paradigms (IAT targeting monogamy vs. adultery and a go/no-go task using female faces as alluring cues). A group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (IAT: incongruent vs. congruent) is reported with cluster-level FWE-corrected results and MNI coordinates (Table 3), satisfying the ‘whole-brain evidence’ requirement. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are presented separately. Although the go/no-go analysis included an ROI constraint for the right VLPFC, the presence of the IAT whole-brain contrast ensures the paper provides an unmasked, task-evoked whole-brain map from a healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI, only connectivity, non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the paper meets inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an event-related 3T fMRI study of healthy adults (N=29; ages 20–35) performing facial emotion recognition (explicit) and age-discrimination (implicit) tasks – a social cognition paradigm (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts and corrected statistical maps/coordinates (Table 1, figures) for the healthy sample, and correlation analyses; results are not ROI-only. Participants fall within the 17–65 range and healthy-group results are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or outside age range) are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion requirements for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (social motor response learning / social inclusion-exclusion) in healthy adults (n=18, mean age 42±12). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (one-group t tests; results thresholded and corrected using FDR whole-brain correction; tables of coordinates provided, e.g., Table II and III, and statistical maps/figures). The healthy adult group is analyzed and reported separately; no disqualifying clinical-only or ROI-only analyses. The task and contrasts clearly probe social processes (perception/understanding of others, social inclusion/exclusion). All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (perception and social-evaluative processing of different laughter types). Sample: healthy adult participants (n=18, mean age 26), within the 17–65 age range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects univariate analyses (e.g., CSL vs TIC, CAT vs COU) with voxelwise thresholds, cluster-level FWE correction, and coordinates/figures defining ROIs — satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the study also reports connectivity (PPI), it includes explicit whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy control group rather than only ROI or connectivity results. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult samples (Experiment 1a/b and Experiment 2; final N=178, mean age 40.9, within 17–65). It implements a social cognition task (EmpaToM) probing empathy and Theory of Mind. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., emotionally negative > neutral videos; ToM > nonToM questions) with voxelwise results, peak coordinates and cluster tables (Tables 1–5) and thresholding details; results are generalizable to the healthy adult group and are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. The study is empirical, not a review, and presents whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and coordinate tables for the healthy/control participants. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (attribute framing and self/other evaluations). Sample consists of healthy adults (final N=19 after exclusions), ages 19–41, within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., task vs control, positive minus negative frame, negative minus positive frame, frame-inconsistent minus frame-consistent) with coordinates and cluster-size thresholds described, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group within-subject contrasts generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study used task-evoked fMRI in a social-related paradigm (direct vs. averted gaze) with a healthy adult sample (N=55 males), it does not report any group-level univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps for the healthy group. Analyses and reported results are ROI-based (amygdala and inferior occipital gyrus) with FWE correction within those masks; no unmasked whole-brain contrasts, coordinate tables, or whole-brain figures/outputs are provided. Therefore it violates the requirement for whole-brain evidence and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception/understanding of others) in healthy adult participants (ten right-handed males, ages 22–32). It reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., atypical vs. typical displays) with voxelwise maps and cluster-corrected results presented in tables of activation peaks and coordinates. The analysis is not limited to ROI or resting-state/connectivity-only methods (although connectivity/GCM is also reported). Age and healthy-sample criteria are met and whole-brain results are clearly described, so the study satisfies all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of affective (social) touch in healthy adults (N=22; ages 19–35). The task is social-related (CT-targeted pleasant touch; relates to affiliation/social perception). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked activation maps (arm>baseline, palm>baseline, arm>palm) using random-effects GLM and provides tables of peak coordinates and figures. Analyses are generalizable to healthy adults and not limited to a narrow subgroup. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=23) using a social cognition task (affective and cognitive Theory of Mind comic-strip task). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (contrasts AToM vs control and CToM vs control), with results FDR-corrected at the cluster level and one-sample t-tests for task activation described in the text and tables/figures. Whole-brain task-evoked univariate maps for the healthy sample are reported/derived (including masked one-sample t-tests), meeting the requirement for healthy-group whole-brain activation. The study is not ROI-only, not solely connectivity or resting-state, and includes adults within the eligible age range (age was modeled as a covariate). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review’s objective.

This is an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (n=17, mean age 26) investigating social perception (observation of social vs. individual actions with gaze manipulations). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (random-effects within-subjects ANOVA) with main effects and interaction maps and coordinates (SPM results, Table 1 and figures). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and results for the healthy adult group are reported and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI with an instructional manipulation (belief of being observed) and reports network-level functional connectivity results. It does not present any group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked (voxelwise) activation maps from a social task. Analyses are connectivity/resting-state contrasts rather than task-evoked whole-brain activation, so it fails the inclusion requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and meets the exclusion criterion for resting-state-only studies.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind — perception/understanding of others) using validated Heider-and-Simmel animations. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (n=20; age range 24–64), falling within the 17–65 inclusion range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (ToM > R, ToM > Baseline, R > Baseline) with voxelwise and cluster-level statistical thresholds and lists significant activations; results are clearly described for the healthy/control group. Analyses include whole-brain and Bayesian evaluations; this is not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical paper. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy, intimacy, perspective-taking: self, loved-one, stranger) using a task with painful vs. neutral animations. Sample: 36 healthy right-handed adults (mean age 23), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (Pain vs Neutral contrasts across perspectives) with FDR-corrected voxel thresholds and stereotactic coordinates in tables and figures, allowing population-level inferences. Although PPI connectivity is also reported, the study includes the required whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants are healthy adults). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this fMRI study used a social interaction task with healthy adult participants (physicians aged 25–37) and reports task-related neural activations related to empathy/compassion, the neuroimaging results are reported from a priori region-of-interest analyses with FWE correction performed within those ROIs. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level voxelwise task activation map (or equivalent whole-brain coordinates/generalizable healthy-group contrast) required by the review inclusion criteria. Therefore it fails the 'whole-brain evidence' inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing about friends vs kin). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=25 females, mean age 23.2), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (friend > kin; parametric linear effects across social network layers) with cluster-corrected results and tables of MNI coordinates and figures. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state only, and provides healthy-group whole-brain maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (self-reference vs other-reference) in healthy adults (N=110, ages 19–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM contrasts (social > baseline, self > other, other > self) using FWE-corrected whole-brain inference and provides activation maps/tables. The healthy-control group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. Although the study also reports DCM effective connectivity, it additionally meets the requirement of whole-brain task activation maps. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) are violated.

The study is a task-based fMRI investigation of social/affiliative processing in healthy adult mothers (ages 22–45) and reports group-level, voxelwise contrasts (e.g., own child vs. fixation, own dog vs. fixation, own child vs. own dog). However, all statistical inference was conducted using an a priori ROI approach with small-volume correction (SVC); significance thresholds and FWE-corrections were applied within ROI masks. The paper does not present or claim unmasked, whole-brain (brain-wide multiple-comparison corrected) task activation maps or whole-brain cluster-corrected results generalizable to a healthy adult population outside ROI-constrained inference. Because the review requires at least one whole-brain, univariate task-evoked statistical map for the healthy group, and this study reports only ROI/SVC-limited voxelwise results, it fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

Although this fMRI study uses a social (Theory of Mind/Reading the Mind in the Eyes) task and includes healthy adult control participants (ages within 18–23 range), the paper reports only between-group contrasts (low-risk controls > high-risk offspring) and does not present an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. The meta-analysis requires a clearly identified whole-brain univariate task-evoked map from a healthy adult group; absence of such within-group whole-brain results means the study does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related (self- and other-reflection; perception/understanding of self and others). (2) Contains a healthy adult control group (n=21) with results reported separately. (3) Reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation maps for the healthy control group (contrasts self>semantic and other>semantic), with voxelwise FWE-corrected thresholds and coordinates (main effects described and Table S1). (4) Not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical analyses. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) fMRI during a social-related task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test, a ToM/social cognition task); (2) sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=18, mean age 26.4, within 17–65); (3) reports group-level, univariate task-evoked contrasts for the healthy group (one-sample t-test for ToM>gender in the placebo condition and paired contrasts), with results given as tables of coordinates and exploratory whole-brain analyses (P<0.001 uncorrected). Although ROI/SVC analyses are reported, whole-brain results and coordinate tables are also provided and clearly described. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI or connectivity analyses, or non-healthy sample) are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (gaze-following to political in-group/out-group faces). Sample: healthy adult participants (n=28; ages 18–29). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., incongruent > congruent), with tables of significant clusters and MNI coordinates and cluster-level FWE correction. Results for the healthy adult group are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, healthy adults within age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study uses task-based fMRI while participants thought about interpersonal social interactions (16 social-interaction conditions), fitting social-related processing (self/others). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=17) reported separately and matched to the autism group. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain GLM within-group contrasts (all social interactions – fixation) for the control group (thresholded SPM contrasts described in the text and shown in figures/tables), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the paper emphasizes multivariate and classification analyses, conventional whole-brain GLM within-group results for the control group are reported, making the study eligible for inclusion in the review.

This study used task-based fMRI during a social cognition (Theory of Mind) task (ToM vs random-motion animations). It includes a healthy adult group (n=20; ages 22–56) with results reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task contrasts for the healthy controls (ToM > random motion) with Talairach coordinates, cluster sizes, and corrected statistics, and describes random-effects analyses—meeting the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, within the age range, and not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusions.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (team membership/group bias) in healthy adult participants (ages 17–43). The study reports task-evoked, group-level whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., action videos vs fixation; own-team vs other-team; decision vs baseline) with cluster-level family-wise error correction (PFWE < 0.05) and provides coordinates, tables, and figures. The sample comprises healthy adult controls and results are reported for the healthy group. The paper includes whole-brain statistical maps/contrast results rather than ROI-only, and does not rely solely on connectivity or resting-state analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (final N=18; ages 21–38). The task is social in nature (cooperation vs. competition; theory-of-mind processes), meeting the construct requirement. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate contrasts (e.g., coop_active > coop_passive, comp_active > comp_passive, active > passive) with cluster-level FWE correction and tables/coordinates (Table 1, Supplementary Tables), satisfying the ‘‘whole-brain evidence’’ inclusion criterion. Although ROI/MVPA analyses are also performed, whole-brain task activation maps from the healthy/control group are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of empathy for pain (a social cognitive task: perception/understanding of others). It includes a healthy young adult group (age 20–30) within the required 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (pain>no pain; pain>baseline) with FWE-corrected maps and coordinate tables across the healthy sample—i.e., voxelwise task-evoked activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Although the study also includes an older group (65–75), the presence of a healthy adult group within 17–65 and clear whole-brain results fulfills the inclusion criteria. Not excluded by any listed exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not non-empirical).

This study is not a task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It reports resting-state functional connectivity analyses (no task-evoked, univariate whole-brain activation maps) and focuses on high-functioning adolescents with autism spectrum disorder plus typically developing adolescents (ages 12–23). Inclusion criteria require fMRI during a social-related task and a healthy adult sample aged 17–65 with whole-brain task activation maps reported for the healthy group. This paper violates the requirement for task-evoked whole-brain maps (reports only resting-state connectivity) and the healthy-group sample comprises adolescents (many <17), so it does not meet the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it uses task-based fMRI probing social-related processing (perspective taking/empathy), with healthy adult participants (n=18, ages 21–31). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (e.g., Self vs Other; View-Pain vs View-NoPain) with cluster- and peak-level inference (FWE-corrected) and tables of MNI coordinates. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and results are clearly generalizable to a healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This paper reports task-based functional MRI in healthy adult participants performing action observation and weight-discrimination tasks that target "Perception and Understanding of Others," a social-related construct. Multiple experiments include healthy control groups (total N across experiments reported; Experiment details show group-level analyses of healthy participants) and the clinical SCA6 group is analyzed separately with control results reported independently. The manuscript presents group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., ActionOBS–CtrlOBS; Sleeve/NoSleeve conditions) with thresholded statistical maps, cluster-wise and peak-level results, and overlap/consistency analyses; figures and threshold information are provided. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. Therefore it fulfills inclusion criteria for fMRI, social-related processing, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked maps, and does not violate exclusion criteria.

While the study uses task-based fMRI of a social (mentalizing) Domino game and includes a healthy adult control group (TD, ages 18–34), it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy group (e.g., voxelwise GLM contrast or coordinate table for TD). Analyses are based on spatially constrained ICA (GIG-ICA) and temporal-sorting regression producing component-level β-weights and component spatial maps. Although they present IC spatial maps and component task-relatedness, these are multivariate ICA-derived networks and component-level effects rather than standard univariate, voxelwise task activation contrasts for the healthy group. The paper therefore lacks the required whole-brain, univariate healthy-group task activation map (or coordinates) specified in the inclusion criteria. This falls under the exclusion criteria for studies reporting only ICA/multivariate component analyses without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task activation map.

This fMRI study directly investigates social-related processing (perception of others’ dynamic vs. static emotional facial expressions). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=13; mean age 24.3, within 17–65) whose results are reported separately. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts for the control group (dynamic vs. static) with cluster- and voxel-level thresholds and displays/listings of activated regions (MTG, FG, AMY, MPFC, IFG), satisfying the whole-brain evidence criterion. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results (DCM is also reported but whole-brain activation maps for the healthy group are clearly provided). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social gesture processing using dynamic, naturalistic stimuli in a healthy adult sample. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., social vs. nonsocial; actor-orientation; face-visibility) with proper statistical correction (TFCE and permutation testing), clearly from the healthy/control group. The sample comprises 20 healthy adults (mean age 21.41, range 16.9–25.7); although one participant is just below 17 (16.9), the group-level healthy adult results are reported and generalizable to adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria (minor age deviation noted, lowering confidence slightly).

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (N=16, mean age 22) using an n-back paradigm manipulating sociality (trustworthiness) and load. Group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses were performed (SPM8; voxel-wise 2×2 repeated-measures ANOVA) and reported with coordinates and cluster results (tables and figures), yielding main effects and interactions generalized to the healthy sample. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range, and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper is empirical and reports whole-brain task-evoked activation maps rather than ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only contrasts. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task: fMRI during a social-related self-referential task (perception/understanding of self). (2) Sample: includes a healthy adult control group (n=15; age range 31–58, within 17–65) with results reported separately. (3) Whole-brain evidence: group-level, voxelwise task-evoked analyses and activation maps for the healthy/control group are reported (figures and voxelwise t-tests; tables of coordinates and ANOVA results provided). Not limited to ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. Therefore eligible for inclusion.

Although this is an fMRI study of social cognition including a healthy control group (n=25, ages 18–60) and a social ToM task, the full-text does not clearly report an unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map or statistical map that is explicitly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The paper mainly presents between-group contrasts (patient vs control), a combined/unclear whole-brain table of activations (Table 2) without specifying healthy-only voxelwise maps, and ROI analyses for group comparisons. Because the review requires at least one clearly reported healthy-group whole-brain univariate task effect (e.g., healthy within-group map or contrast reported voxelwise/coordinates attributable to healthy controls), this criterion is not satisfied. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing/representation of others’ mental states) in healthy adults (N=20; ages 18–27). The task is social-related (participants judged scenarios evoking 60 mental states). The paper reports whole-brain analyses: voxelwise multivariate searchlight results and parallel univariate whole-brain regression maps, with cluster-corrected results and tables of significant regions (Tables S2–S3, figures showing whole-brain maps). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and includes group-level, generalizable healthy-adult whole-brain task effects. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=19, mean age 27.7) examining emotion processing and mirror neuron responses during a task pairing hand actions and shapes. The task is social-relevant (emotion processing and perception/understanding of others via putative mirror system). The paper reports group-level, univariate, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., untrained>trained; full-brain cluster-corrected results and ROI and whole-brain analyses are presented and tabulated), which satisfy the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from a healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it should be included.

This is an empirical fMRI study of moral reasoning (a social-cognition task involving understanding self/others and empathy) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=28, age 18–55) reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level, univariate task-evoked contrasts for the healthy control group (one-sample analyses and tables of coordinates; FWE-corrected results and whole-brain flexible-factorial analyses are presented). Results for the healthy group are generalizable to healthy adults and not limited to a narrow subgroup. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and contains original fMRI data in healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (joint attention/representation of what another person sees) in healthy adults (n=12 analyzed, ages 20–31). The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate contrasts (body > place and place > body), displays whole-brain statistical maps (p<.01) and provides coordinate tables (Table 1). Tasks and methods are clearly described and results are reported for the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study includes a healthy adult control group (n=15; ages 17–34) and reports within-group, whole-brain univariate task-evoked activation maps for the healthy/control group (Table 2, figures). The task involves imagining performing actions shown by others (body-checking vs neutral actions) and taps social-related processing constructs (perception/understanding of self and others, mentalizing/mirror systems), which fits the review’s social processing domain. Results for healthy controls are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. The paper does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity/resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (empathic concern elicited by film clips) in healthy adults (n=26, mean age 30.3). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and voxelwise results (see Tables 1 and 2 and SPM contrasts; FWE cluster-corrected results are provided). The experimental task is clearly social (empathy/emotion processing), and analyses include whole-brain GLM contrasts and parametric modulation maps for the healthy sample. It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (explicit mental simulation of another person’s actions/feelings—perception and understanding of others). Sample: 20 healthy adults (ages 21–47), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked analyses (GLM second-level SPM-t maps and contrasts such as simulate > watch, simulate losing > watch, etc.), thresholded and FDR-corrected, and presents corresponding figures and regional results. Thus it provides generalizable healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps (not only ROI or connectivity-only results). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion requirements for the meta-analysis.

Although the study used fMRI in healthy adult dyads during social interactions (cooperation vs. competition) and thus meets the sample and task-domain criteria, it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked (voxelwise) activation map for the healthy group. The analyses are data-driven (group-ICA and inter-subject correlation) and present ICA component spatial maps and between-brain coupling statistics rather than conventional GLM-derived voxelwise task activation contrasts or within-group univariate statistical maps. Per the exclusion criteria, studies that report only ICA/connectivity-type or inter-brain coupling analyses without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task activation map must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=17, age range 21–46) using a task probing social-cognitive processing (why/how action judgments; mentalizing/theory-of-mind constructs). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (contrasts of Why vs How and parametric LOA effects) with cluster-forming thresholding and cluster-level FWE correction; whole-brain results and coordinates are reported (main text and Supplementary Tables). The sample is within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported directly. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and is empirical with original fMRI data. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of social-related fMRI studies in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (affiliation vs. isolation) using task-evoked BOLD fMRI. It includes a healthy younger adult group (mean age 20.75, within the 17–65 range) and reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate voxelwise analyses with coordinates and tables (see Tables 2–4 and conjunction/contrast results). Although an older group (>65) is also included, results for the healthy younger adults are analyzed and reported separately via conjunctions and contrasts, and whole-brain task effects for the healthy group are presented. The study does not rely solely on ROIs or connectivity analyses and provides whole-brain task activation maps/generalizable group results, meeting the inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study employing a social incentive delay task (social and monetary conditions) in a cohort of healthy adults (N=63; ages ~20–36). The paper reports group-level, univariate task-evoked whole-brain activation results (tables and figures) including FWE-corrected whole-brain and ROI-corrected contrasts for social>monetary and monetary>social during anticipation and outcome phases. Healthy participant results are reported separately and are generalizable to the healthy adult population. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses and includes coordinate tables/whole-brain maps, meeting all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports original fMRI data in a sample of 20 healthy adult participants performing cross-modal face–voice perception tasks (socially relevant perception/communication). The abstract and methods describe group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts using multiple statistical criteria (super-additive, max, mean) that identified brain regions (e.g., left hippocampus, occipital and temporal cortices) rather than ROI-only results. Although a PPI connectivity analysis is reported, it is supplemental to whole-brain task-evoked findings. The paper is empirical, involves healthy adults within the target age range, and provides group-level voxelwise task activation results generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20 young adults) who viewed dynamic social interaction videos during scanning. The paper reports group-level task-evoked activation with statistical results (e.g., significant right>left activation in amygdaloid complex, inferior frontal gyrus, fusiform gyrus, temporal gyri; p<0.0001), indicating whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participants fall within the adult age range (17–65). The reported effects are within the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are triggered (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not non-empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-scene/person interaction perception in healthy adults (N=12; ages 21–31). The task involves social-related processing (judging sex while viewing congruent/incongruent/non-interacting dyads) and the manuscript reports group-level univariate whole-brain task contrasts (voxelwise threshold p<.001, cluster-based p<.05) with peak coordinates and tables/figures (e.g., Table 3, whole-brain contrasts incongruent>congruent, etc.). Results for the healthy adult sample are reported directly (not limited to a subgroup), and analyses include both whole-brain and ROI/MVPA but are not ROI-only. The study does not fall under any exclusion criteria (no connectivity-only, no patient-only sample, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study in 40 healthy adult (heterosexual) males (mean age 25.8), using a social-related task (interpersonal touch; manipulation of perceived toucher sex). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical results (whole-brain contrasts and coordinates are provided, with family-wise error corrections and ROI follow-ups). The contrasts of interest (e.g., Female TouchOXT>Female TouchPLC; Female vs Male touch under placebo) are clearly reported for the healthy control sample. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and the reported results are generalizable to healthy adults (not limited to a narrowly defined subgroup). The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and includes whole-brain activation maps/tables, meeting all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria for the review.

The study uses task-based fMRI with social stimuli (faces and gaze) in healthy adult men (age range within 17–65). It reports group-level task-evoked activation differences (direct vs averted gaze) in regions including amygdala, fusiform gyrus, and anterior superior temporal cortex, and reports functional connectivity findings; these are empirical, voxelwise group results (not ROI-only or resting-state-only), and results are reported for healthy control groups (normal fear scorers) and a matched healthy subgroup (low fear scorers). Thus it meets the review’s fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-activation reporting criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=25, mean age ~25) using task-based imaging of faces with manipulated facial color — a social-perception/relevant social communication construct (perception/understanding of others: emotion/health cues). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (natural-colored faces vs. scrambled images) with voxelwise results and cluster coordinates (Table 1, group-level maps at P<1e-3 uncorrected), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results for healthy participants are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (evaluative judgments of guilt and embarrassment). Sample: 19 healthy adult participants (ages within 17–65), reported separately. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise, whole-brain random-effects analyses (contrasts G–N, E–N, E–G, G–E) with tables of peak coordinates and figures; results are not limited to ROIs and are task-evoked (block-design emotional judgment). It is empirical fMRI data from healthy adults and meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria (whole-brain univariate maps, healthy adult group). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply.

This fMRI study uses a social-processing task (Frith-Happé animations) and includes a healthy adult control group (NT; n=23, ages 19–56). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (one-sample t-tests and whole-brain results for each group, with supplementary whole-brain results referenced) clearly identified for the healthy/control group. The healthy sample falls within the 17–65 age range. The study also provides activation maps and coordinate-based results for within-group contrasts, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is empirical, task-based fMRI (not ROI-only or connectivity-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages ~19–33). It uses a social interactive task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) vs a non-social control, and reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (PD > Gamble) with tables of activation coordinates and voxelwise thresholding (random-effects analysis). Whole-brain connectivity and Granger analyses supplement but do not replace the univariate whole-brain results. Participants are healthy adults and results for this group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

The study does not include a healthy adult control group generalizable to the healthy population: both comparison groups are incarcerated offenders (psychotic and nonpsychotic), i.e., a forensic/special sample rather than a healthy community adult sample. Additionally, the primary neuroimaging results are ICA-based connectivity/component analyses and between-group contrasts; the paper does not report a within-group, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map clearly identified as coming from a healthy/control group. Therefore it fails the sample and whole-brain evidence inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (social reflection: self- and other-judgments) in a healthy adult sample (n=22; ages within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (SR > AL, S > AL, O > AL) with cortical surface maps, cluster-corrected results and Talairach coordinates (Tables/Figures). Although resting-state and ROI analyses are also included, whole-brain univariate task activation maps for the healthy group are clearly reported, satisfying all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluations — Perception/Understanding of Self). Sample: healthy adults (n=31, age range 19–24, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and regression analyses with voxelwise results (e.g., SC vs SA, OA vs OC, SA vs Fixation) and provides coordinate tables and statistical thresholds (voxel-wise p<0.001, cluster-level FWE p<0.05) and figures. Although additional PPI connectivity analyses are included, the study also clearly reports univariate whole-brain activation maps for the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (final N=14; ages 18–30) that explicitly probes a social cognitive process (trustworthiness evaluation of faces). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, univariate task-evoked analyses with whole-brain statistical parametric maps and tables of coordinates (including small-volume corrected results in regions of interest and whole-brain contrasts), clearly derived from the healthy/control sample.
