This paper reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (integration of non-verbal human vocalizations and facial movements—social communication/perception of others). The fMRI sample includes healthy adult participants (n=10, ages 24–37). Group-level voxelwise univariate analyses are reported (voxel-by-voxel t tests, group activation maps versus rest, AV versus AUD+VIS contrasts, cluster-correction and Talairach normalization), with results presented in figures and tables. The study is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain, task-evoked activation in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related Theory of Mind (visual joke) task. The paper includes a healthy control group (n=13; adults age ~29) and reports within-group, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (ToM vs Physical) for the control group with coordinates and cluster-corrected statistics (see Table 3 and related figures). The study is not limited to ROI or connectivity analyses and provides univariate whole-brain maps/generalizable healthy-group task effects. Although clinical/high-risk groups are also included, results for the healthy adult control group are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (learning others’ inter-temporal preferences and self–other valuation) in healthy adult participants (behavioral N=27; fMRI N=29 with 2 exclusions). The authors report group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses (GLM contrasts, cluster-level FWE correction) with peak coordinates and statistical values (e.g., mPFC, visual cortex, STS, striatum), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task clearly probes perception/understanding of others and social influence. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adults (n=14, mean age 25) investigating observation and motor imagery of meaningful face and upper-limb movements, including socially meaningful gestures (social communication). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (conjunctions, main effects, contrasts) with FWE-corrected thresholds and MNI coordinates in tables and SPM figures. Results for the healthy sample are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-, connectivity-, or patient-only focused. Therefore it satisfies the inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain group-level task activation maps).

While the study uses fMRI in healthy adult samples and includes social tasks (theory-of-mind, attribution-of-attention), its primary analyses are localized ICA performed within a temporoparietal ROI and regression of IC time courses to task predictors. The paper does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation map (e.g., a conventional GLM contrast like belief>photo) for the healthy group. Reported voxelwise results are seed-to-voxel connectivity maps (functional connectivity), and the spatial IC maps/winner-take-all maps are constrained to the TPJ ROI. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain univariate task activation evidence and meets the exclusion criteria (ROI/ICA- or connectivity-focused results only).

This is an fMRI experiment in healthy adults (N=18, ages ~25) investigating social-communication constructs (vitality forms of speech and actions). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Vitality vs Control) with MNI coordinates and FWE-corrected results, including conjunction analyses and tables of activations. Whole-brain analyses (not ROI-only) are presented and clearly described for the healthy control sample. Although PPI connectivity is also reported, univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group are available, satisfying inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range participants) are violated.

The study reports task-based fMRI in both healthy adolescents and a separate healthy adult group (ages 22.6–30.4). The adult group is within the 17–65 range. The paper provides group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses and reports coordinates and figures for adult task contrasts (e.g., You-rest, Mom-rest, conjunctions), with unmasked whole-brain results and corrected thresholds described. The task probes social-related constructs (direct and reflected self-appraisals; self-perception and perspective-taking), which fall under the review’s eligible domains. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, adult results reported separately). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Empirical fMRI study of implicit false-belief (theory-of-mind) processing — a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Sample: healthy adult participants (mean age 22.7; final n for MRI analyses reported), within 17–65. Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (whole-brain GLM contrasts; belief > photo/map) with SPMs and peak Talairach coordinates and cluster thresholds; not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly described and generalizable. No exclusion criteria met. Therefore study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this fMRI study includes a healthy adult control group (right-handed males, mean age ~27) and uses a social-related task (explicit and implicit processing of emotional facial expressions), the paper does not present a clear, unmasked whole-brain, group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. The Results primarily report activations for the autistic group, main effects (task and diagnosis) and diagnosis × task interactions, and between-group contrasts (controls > autism), but do not provide an independent within-group whole-brain statistical map or univariate contrast clearly attributable to the healthy group that is generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked map and must be excluded.

Although the study uses fMRI with healthy adult participants and reports group-level whole-brain task contrasts, its experimental paradigm probes sexual arousal and incentive/reward responses to erotic stimuli across sexual orientations. The meta-analysis objective targets social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception/understanding of self or others). The present study’s primary outcomes concern sexual arousal and reward-system activation, not social cognitive processes or social interaction/communication constructs. Therefore it does not address the review’s targeted social-related tasks and should be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=20, mean age ~25, within 17–65). The task is social (Cyberball) probing social exclusion/affiliation processes. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (e.g., social exclusion > fair play; same- vs other-gender exclusion) with tables of coordinates and cluster-corrected results and figures, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and includes within-group healthy adult analyses generalizable to the healthy population. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=32, mean age ~24.7). The task manipulated social context (collaborative, individual, competitive) during effort production and explicitly probes social constructs (collaboration/competition, social position). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses using SPM8, with clusterwise FWE correction and reported activation peaks/coordinates (e.g., ventral basal ganglia, TPJ, mPFC). Results for the healthy adult sample are presented separately and are generalizable to the healthy group (no clinical sample reported). The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: 1) Task: the study used task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (naturalistic social-evaluative videos probing social evaluation/mentalizing, affiliation/communication and perception of others). 2) Sample: healthy adult participants (N=37; mean age 24.8, within 17–65). 3) Whole-brain evidence: the paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., negative>neutral, positive>neutral), conjunction analyses and FWE-corrected results presented in tables and figures (Tables 2–4, whole-brain FWE-corrected p<.05). 4) No exclusion criteria are triggered (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants are within the target age range). Therefore this empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults should be INCLUDED in the meta-analysis.

This is a functional MRI study of social processing (self–other merging during cooperation and competition) in healthy adults (final N=24; age 19–31). The task is explicitly social (ratings and decisions about self vs relevant other in cooperative/competitive contexts). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (identifying pgACC and area 9 and other whole-brain effects) rather than only ROI or connectivity results. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy sample. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social interaction (mutual gaze and joint attention) in healthy adult participants (mean ages ~21–23, all right-handed except one). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and cluster-level statistics (Tables 2–5, voxel coordinates, FWE-corrected results) including contrasts for JA conditions (IJA/RJA) and MG1/MG2 (MG2–MG1). Results are generalizable to healthy adults and are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=24, ages 18–27) that examines neural correlates of abstract vs. concrete mindsets using Why-How and Categories-Exemplars tasks involving social-cognitive processes (action identification/mentalizing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts analyzed with SPM5 (one-sample t-tests) and provides coordinates and cluster-corrected results in Table 2 and figures. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes task-evoked whole-brain maps for the healthy control group. All inclusion criteria are met (healthy adult sample, social-related task, whole-brain univariate results). No exclusion criteria are violated.

Population: Healthy adult participants (n=10, ages 20–29). Task: auditory perception of human footsteps (biological motion) involving perception/understanding of others; authors explicitly reference the ‘social cognition’ area (posterior STS) and biological motion, which maps onto social-related processing constructs. Whole-brain, group-level univariate results: contrast ‘footstep minus rest’ reported with t-values, cluster coordinates and a group random-effects analysis; results presented in Table 1 and supplementary whole-brain maps. Study is empirical fMRI in healthy adults and reports an univariate task-evoked whole-brain activation map generalizable to healthy adults. Although the paper also contains connectivity analyses, it includes the required whole-brain task activation data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study of social appraisal (preference judgments of emotional faces) that includes a healthy adult comparison group (n=21; mean age 39.8±10.3, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (PREF>GENDER) with tables and figures showing within-group activation maps for the control group (coordinates and corrected clusters provided). Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and provides univariate, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy participants, satisfying all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (Princeton undergraduates; mean age 19.5, within 17–65). The task is explicitly social (viewing photographs of social groups and making affective/social-cognitive judgments about others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (GLM contrasts vs fixation, 3-versus-1 contrasts), random-effects analyses, Talairach coordinates, and cluster statistics (tables/figures), not ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Thus it satisfies the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults and reports whole-brain univariate healthy-group task activation maps.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy young adults (ages 21–24) that includes a social-context manipulation (peer observation) relevant to social processing. The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate activation contrasts for both tasks (Go/No-Go and Stoplight) and provides thresholded/unthresholded maps (NeuroVault). Healthy adult sample is within 17–65 and results for the healthy group are reported. Although the paper emphasizes connectivity, it also includes traditional whole-brain activation/subtraction analyses (e.g., No-Go > Go, Risk > Safe), satisfying the requirement for univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical, task-based fMRI study of social communication (emotional speech prosody) in healthy adult participants (n=22, mean age 24.8, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (emotional > neutral prosody) with cluster-corrected results (PFDR < 0.05) and associated tables/figures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain activation maps are clearly reported for the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria are met (not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical study), and results are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This study uses task-based fMRI including explicit social cognition tasks (social videos and social texts probing others' beliefs/emotions). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=45; mean age 20.5, range 19–23). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and random-effects analyses with figures and peak coordinate tables (Appendix A), demonstrating generalizable healthy-group univariate activation maps. It is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain results. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=30, ages 19–39) that investigates social-related processing (kinship/affiliation, moral decision-making, mentalizing) using task paradigms. The paper reports group-level whole-brain results: (a) voxelwise inter-subject correlation (ISC) analyses across the whole brain with FDR correction and cluster reporting, and (b) a separate GLM analysis of a moral-dilemma task with whole-brain, cluster-corrected activations (tables of clusters/peak coordinates and unthresholded maps available). The sample is within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy group are presented. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, and includes univariate, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of personal familiarity (a social-related process) and reports whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts for the healthy control group, the healthy participants are described as 'healthy elderly' and were recruited as an aging control group. Participant ages are not provided but the term 'elderly' and focus on aging strongly indicate they are older than the review's upper age limit (65). The review requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65; therefore the study population does not meet the sample age criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of emotional prosody comprehension (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others’ emotions) in healthy adult participants (n=19 males, ages 18–51). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate contrasts (emotional vs neutral; complex vs simple emotions), thresholding and cluster-correction methods, and localization of activations (including medial PFC, STG, IFG, etc.), fulfilling the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. The task is social-related (complex/social emotions, ToM-related processing). The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy group separately. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed connectivity only, not between-group-only contrasts, and is empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

Although the study used task-based fMRI in a healthy adult sample (n=8, ages within 17–65) and investigated socially relevant interpersonal touch, it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (e.g., GLM contrast maps or tables of voxelwise coordinates). The analysis is based on independent component analysis (ICA) to derive spatial components and time courses; only ICA-derived component maps and time series are presented. Per the review’s exclusion criteria, studies that report only ICA/other multivariate/resting-state-like analyses without an accompanying univariate whole-brain healthy-group task activation map must be excluded. Therefore the study does not meet the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (age 18–45) that employed a social-related task (viewing/regulating responses to images of human suffering—perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (suffering vs. neutral; Group × Redistribution Rank interaction) with whole-brain corrected results identifying clusters (e.g., IPC, DLPFC) and presents these results in figures/tables. Although connectivity/PPI analyses are also reported, univariate whole-brain effects for the healthy sample are clearly described and generalizable. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only or non-empirical) apply.

This is an fMRI study using a social cognition task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes Task) with a healthy adult control group (n=25; mean age ~31). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task activation results for healthy controls (descriptions and Supplementary Tables S2 and S3), and uses standard whole-brain fMRI analysis (FSL) with cluster-level FWE correction. Although the study includes a clinical Tourette group, healthy-group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or lack of healthy-group whole-brain task map) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=13, mean age 24.2) using a social-cognitive task (self- and friend-referent personality trait judgments; perception/understanding of self and others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (SPM contrasts, random-effects second-level ANOVA) with tables of coordinates and statistical maps described in the text. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes within-group healthy adult results generalizable to the population. Age range and participant health meet inclusion criteria. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=12, mean age 27.3±4.7) that uses a social perception task (classification of animated agents’ actions; relates to perception/understanding of others and mentalizing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (SPM2 random-effects; tables and figures of activation clusters with coordinates and FDR-corrected maps, e.g., Tables 1–2 and whole-brain contrasts). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and healthy participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social perception in healthy adults (n=21, ages 23–33). The task involved viewing dyadic nonverbal interactions and rating naturalness during event-related fMRI. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (multiple contrasts, cluster- and voxel-thresholds) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster statistics, fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. Sample falls within 17–65 and results for the healthy control group are reported separately. The study uses task-evoked activation maps (not only ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing about groups and individuals) in healthy adult participants (Experiment 1: N=25, ages 19–27; Experiment 2: N=14, ages 18–23), meeting the sample age criterion. The task is task-evoked and social-related (theory of mind/mental state inference). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., group mental > group physical; member mental > member physical; individual mental > individual physical) with stereotaxic coordinates, cluster sizes, and corrected thresholds, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses include MVPA but also univariate whole-brain results; it is not ROI-only or resting-state/connectivity-only. No exclusion criteria apply, so the study should be included.

This study uses fMRI during a clearly social-related task (anticipation of touching an animate vs inanimate target). The sample comprises healthy adults (32 right-handed males age 21–33; task fMRI n=21), which falls within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task contrasts (paired-sample t-test for anticipation of animate vs inanimate) with FDR-corrected statistical maps and anatomically labeled coordinates, and also reports whole-brain covariate analyses with narcissism scores. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain task-evoked maps) and does not violate any exclusion criteria (ROIs/rest-only or patient-only analyses).

This is an fMRI study of social processing (reciprocity in a Trust Game) in healthy adult participants (final imaging sample N=19, ages 18–30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts for the healthy sample (e.g., Baseline and Emotionally Challenging conditions with tables of activated regions and MNI coordinates; Table 3 and figures). Analyses are not limited to ROIs or resting-state/connectivity-only results. The task and contrasts reflect social-related constructs (reciprocity, altruism, selfishness). No exclusion criteria are met; results for healthy adults are reported separately and are generalizable within the specified age range. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

The study uses fMRI with a social task (Cyberball) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=17, ages within 17–65). However, the manuscript reports primarily between-group contrasts (BPD vs HC, NSSI vs HC, conjunctions) and does not present an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map (e.g., inclusion > passive watching) clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The results focus on differential activations and between-group comparisons rather than an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task effect. Per the exclusion criteria (studies that report only between-group contrasts without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task effect), this paper does not meet all inclusion requirements and should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/understanding of others via viewing facial expressions of disgust). Sample: 27 healthy adult participants (mean age 27, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (canonical disgust vs neutral, distaste vs neutral, canonical vs distaste) with thresholding and tables/figures of activations and coordinates; whole-brain results survive FDR correction in several regions. Although an ROI SVC was applied for the insula, whole-brain analyses and coordinate tables are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adults reported separately). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=31, ages 18–26) investigating neural responses during a social-reward gambling task (self, friend, antagonist). The task probes social-related constructs (perception/understanding of others; affiliation/relationship effects). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (within-subject ANOVAs, Person × Outcome interaction) with peak coordinates and tables (Tables 1–2) and figures, and reports regions surviving FDR/FWE small-volume correction. Results for the healthy adult sample are reported clearly and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, age within range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (gaze shifts/joint attention) in healthy adult participants (behavioral n=10; fMRI n=12; ages 18–40). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level, voxelwise task-evoked analyses using SPM2 with random-effects second-level ANOVA and multiple whole-brain contrasts (e.g., gaze shift vs no movement; incorrect vs correct; social vs unsocial), and provides tables and figures of activated loci and statistical maps. It is not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

While this is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants that uses social/attachment narratives as a task, the reported neuroimaging results are seed-based resting-state functional connectivity (left/right caudate nucleus) measured during post-narrative rest. The paper does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation maps derived from the narrative listening task itself. Per the review's exclusion criteria, studies reporting only seed-based connectivity or resting-state analyses without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map must be excluded. Therefore this study does not meet the ‘whole-brain task-evoked map’ inclusion criterion and should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults: participants judged facing-toward vs away point-light and human-like walkers, a social-related task. Sample: 16 healthy adults (mean age 22.75), which falls within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported. The paper reports group-level, univariate, task-evoked whole-brain analyses (second-level contrasts, FWE-corrected results, stereotaxic coordinates reported in tables/figures) rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. The analyses and results are generalizable to a healthy adult group (not limited to a narrow subgroup). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (attribution of intentions/theory-of-mind) in healthy adults (n=12, ages 21–31). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise, whole-brain task contrasts (Composer > Computer) with a second-level random-effects analysis and tables of peak coordinates and corrected cluster-level statistics. The task is task-evoked (auditory music listening with agency manipulation), not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and results for the healthy control group are reported. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study of gender perception (a form of ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’), which qualifies as social-related processing. The sample comprises healthy adults (n=15 analyzed; ages 19–42), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxel-wise analyses (random-effects GLM; contrast gender-different > gender-same) with cluster-corrected maps and reported Talairach coordinates and figures, not limited to ROI-only results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state-only, non-healthy-only samples, or non-empirical paper) are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study used task-based fMRI (verbal fluency and Hayling sentence completion) assessing verbal executive function and response inhibition, not social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, self/other perception). Although healthy adult controls are included and whole-brain within-group activation maps are reported, the tasks do not target social cognition. Therefore it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion of using fMRI during a social-related task.

This is an fMRI study of social decision-making (Trust Game/reciprocity) in healthy adults (final N=18, age 18–22). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., defect>reciprocate) and regression analyses with coordinates and tables (MNI coordinates, cluster thresholds), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task is clearly social (trust/reciprocity, perspective-taking) and results for the healthy participant group are reported separately. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and fits the review objective of identifying fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n≈27; ages 21–33). The task is social-related (processing 'why'/'how' of actions — mentalizing/understanding others), and the paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and conjunction analyses with voxelwise results and coordinate tables, cluster-wise correction, and Neurosynth validation. It is not ROI-only, nor resting-state or connectivity-only, and results are reported for the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (mentalizing, empathy, prosocial decisions) in healthy adults. Sample: healthy right-handed female adults (mean age 22.7, N≈30–32), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses and contrasts (e.g., Mentalizing > baseline; Dissimilar > Similar; Empathy Painful > Non-Painful), with cluster-level correction (P=0.05 corrected; voxel-level P=0.001) and tables/coordinates. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and presents healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

Although this is an fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adult participants (ages in range, n=36) and uses a task-evoked design, the reported neuroimaging results were constrained to a priori small-volume–corrected analyses within a bilateral vACC ROI. The manuscript describes group-level GLMs but the reported activation findings are presented only after ROI small-volume correction (no unmasked, whole‑brain group-level task activation maps or whole‑brain coordinates for primary task contrasts are reported). Therefore the paper does not provide the required whole‑brain, voxelwise healthy-group task activation map and meets the exclusion criterion for ROI‑only results.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (action/interaction observation; perception/understanding of others). Sample: healthy adult participants (n=29, ages 18–28). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Observation > Neutral; 2H DIFF > 2H SAME) with FWE-corrected statistical maps and peak coordinates (Table 1), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although PPI connectivity is also reported, the study includes univariate task activation maps rather than only ROI or connectivity results. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social-emotional face processing (fearful vs calm faces), directly targeting social-related processing. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=13, mean age ~40, within 17–65) and reports separate within-group, whole-brain univariate activation results for the control group (Tables/Figures showing voxelwise activation peaks and coordinates, including amygdala, STS, etc.). The paper provides group-level statistical maps/coordinate tables for the healthy/control group that are generalizable to healthy adults. Although the study also includes a premutation group, the healthy control results are reported separately. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are present). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (empathy for pain) in healthy adult participants (male, age 18–40). The paper reports group-level, univariate, task-evoked whole-brain analyses (e.g., INJECTION>QTIP and BIOPSY>QTIP contrasts) with voxelwise family-wise error correction and reports peak coordinates and conjunction results, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Participants are healthy adults and results are presented at the group level (stress and control healthy groups), with clearly described task contrasts and whole-brain statistical maps/coordinates. The study is empirical, reports task-evoked activation maps generalizable to healthy adults, and does not fall into exclusion categories (ROIs-only, resting-state-only, or non-healthy-only samples). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social evaluation (social cognition/perception of others) using a task requiring positive/negative judgments of target persons — directly relevant to the review objective. The sample is healthy adults (N=20, ages 18–29). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (a multilevel whole-brain model with reported clusters, MNI coordinates, thresholds, and tables of activations) derived from the healthy participant group. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and results are within a healthy adult sample). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of a clearly social-related task (vocal emotion recognition) and reports whole-brain, group-level univariate activation maps, the sample consists of adolescents aged 8–19 and no separate healthy adult group (age 17–65) is analyzed or reported independently. While a few participants are aged 17–19, the paper presents results for the combined 8–19 sample and continuous age effects rather than an adult-only subgroup. The review’s inclusion criteria require at least one healthy adult group (17–65) with its own whole-brain task activation results. Because the adult-age subgroup is not separately reported/analysed, the study does not meet the sample criterion and must be excluded.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (stereotype/social-category judgments). Participants were healthy adults (N=19, ages 19–28). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects univariate contrasts (e.g., social>non-social and non-social>social) with peak coordinates/tables and corrections (P<0.05, corrected), indicating task-evoked healthy-group whole-brain maps. Analyses are not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and results pertain to the healthy adult group. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (n=37) and reports task-evoked fMRI activation/coordinates for that group, all activation and connectivity analyses were performed within an a priori combined region-of-interest mask (fronto-temporal ROIs) with voxels restricted to that mask. The paper therefore does not provide an unmasked, whole-brain group-level univariate task activation map for healthy adults. It also emphasizes seed/ROI-based connectivity analyses. This violates the inclusion criterion requiring whole-brain, voxelwise healthy-group task activation results and meets the exclusion criterion for ROI-only analyses.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (interactive emotional alignment/social influence) in healthy adults (n=20, mean age 23.95). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses (random-effects), including parametric modulators and tables/figures of activations that survived clusterwise FWE correction over the whole brain. Results include whole-brain correlations during anticipation and picture-viewing phases (insula, DLPFC, amygdala, ventral striatum) reported in tables and figures. It is not ROI-only, nor connectivity-only, and presents healthy-group task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: uses task-based fMRI during a social-feedback paradigm probing social inclusion/exclusion (social-related processing). Sample comprises healthy adolescents/young adults (N=56 analyzed; ages 17–20) within the eligible age range (≥17). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise group-level univariate contrasts (positive>neutral, negative>neutral, conjunction) with familywise error correction and coordinates/cluster results, clearly from the healthy participant group. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group contrasts. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an event-related fMRI study of persuasion/‘expert power’, clearly social cognition (perception/understanding of others, social influence). Participants are healthy adults (young females, n=24 with group analyses on 18/16 after exclusions) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (SME, SAE, expertise main effects and interactions) with cluster correction and tables/figures of activations (including whole-brain maps and coordinate tables); ROI small-volume corrections are additionally reported but do not replace whole-brain results. The study is empirical with original fMRI data and healthy-group results generalizable to adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Task-based fMRI study of social processing (facial emotion recognition) in adults; includes a healthy adult control group (n=14) with results reported separately; reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (within-group contrast NTOXT>PLA showing clusters in inferior frontal gyrus and fusiform gyrus) and full brain tables/coordinates (Table 2). Age range and task meet inclusion; not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly described. Therefore meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=14 analyzed; ages 23–50) that implemented a social-related task (valence appraisal of social vs non-social images). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (social > non-social contrast) with voxelwise thresholding and FDR correction, plus conjunction and ROI analyses; results are presented as whole-brain maps and described in the text/figures. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and healthy. The study does not restrict to ROI-only or connectivity-only results and reports generalizable group-level activation maps for the healthy/control sample. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria. Note: sample size is small but does not disqualify inclusion per criteria.

This is an fMRI study of dynamic audio-visual emotion perception (a social cognition task: perception/understanding of others). Participants are healthy adults (Study 1: n=10, ages 18–33; Study 2: n=5, ages 18–23). The paper reports group-level, univariate, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts and whole-brain analyses with coordinate tables and conjunctions (Study 1 uses random-effects group analysis; whole-brain results and peak coordinates are reported). The study is not limited to ROI-only, nor resting-state or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain task fMRI of social processing.

Although the study used fMRI in healthy adults and includes sentences with some social content, its primary aim was general semantic/sentence representation, not a social-related task per the review constructs. Key inclusion requires a study to report at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy group (e.g., GLM contrast or t-map). This paper uses multivariate regression/decoding and factor analysis and reports factor-related voxel clusters, but does not present a conventional univariate, group-level whole-brain task activation map (main effect or within-group contrast) clearly identified as such. Because it does not meet the whole-brain univariate map requirement and is not primarily a social-processing task, it should be excluded.

This is an original, task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=20; ages 23–39). The task directly probes social-related processing (judgments of ambiguous social interactions: social coordination vs relationship familiarity). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain voxelwise analyses with contrasts (e.g., rough > no priming; rough > smooth) and reports FDR-corrected results with peak coordinates and statistical maps/tables. All inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain univariate task-evoked results) are satisfied, and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, outside age range, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study should be included in the meta-analysis of fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (observation of mouth actions, empathy/social communication) in healthy adult participants (N=60, ages 18–60). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked analyses (within-group contrasts and between-group ANOVAs) with voxelwise results and tables of MNI coordinates, thresholded at p<0.05 FWE and described as random-effects analyses. Although seed-based functional connectivity is also reported, the study additionally provides unmasked, whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy adult groups. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and results for healthy groups are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (naturalistic mentalising) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=22, ages 19–46). The paper reports within-group whole-brain univariate task contrasts for the control group (ToM > physical inference), with family-wise error–corrected clusters and peak coordinates presented in Table 3 and figures, satisfying the requirement for group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. The study also separates control-group results from the ASD group. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only or connectivity-only reporting) apply.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (social preference task) in healthy adults (N=21, ages 23–51 within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Preference > Gender) thresholded at p<0.05 FDR and lists activation peak coordinates and figures (Tables 1–3, Figures 1–4), which are clearly described as coming from the healthy sample. The study is not ROI-only and includes whole-brain results alongside connectivity (PPI) analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion requirements for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study manipulating social competition (competition vs no-competition) during a working memory/learning task in healthy adult participants (female, ages 18–35; n=20). The authors report whole-brain, group-level univariate random-effects GLM results and provide voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Competition > No Competition) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster statistics and figures showing activation in mPFC, PCC/precuneus, STS, etc. The sample is within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. The paper also includes additional ROI analyses but is not ROI-only. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of face perception (a form of social perception/understanding of others), meeting the review’s scope. It includes a healthy adult sample (51 adults, ages 18–42) reported separately. The paper reports group‑level, whole‑brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Face > Object/Texture) with voxelwise statistical maps and cluster thresholds used for ROI definition and figures showing whole‑brain activation. Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=10, mean age 26.9) that investigates self-face recognition (a social-cognition construct: perception/understanding of self) using morphed self vs highly familiar other faces. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (self>other and other>self) with thresholding and tables of MNI coordinates and figures, and additional self-rest and other-rest contrasts; results are clearly from the healthy/control sample. The design and reported analyses are univariate task-evoked whole-brain results, not ROI-only or resting-state/connectivity-only. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (judgments of pride, a self-conscious emotion implicating theory-of-mind/social cognition) in healthy adult participants (N=16, ages ~21). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (pride vs neutral, joy vs neutral, pride vs joy) and provides coordinate tables and thresholding details; whole-brain inference and ROI thresholds are described. Results are clearly reported for the healthy control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and does not rely solely on connectivity or between-group contrasts. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion requirements for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=26, mean age 29.4) using a social-related task (judgments about meaning relatedness of social concepts vs. animal function concepts). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts and tables of coordinates (e.g., social vs. animal function; Table 1; whole-brain and ROI analyses, conjunction analyses) generalizable to a healthy adult sample. The study is not ROI-only, nor is it connectivity- or resting-state-only. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and healthy-group results are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social cognition (monitoring others’ decisions/mentalizing) in healthy adults (N=12, mean age 21). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise second-level random-effects analyses (F-contrasts) with reported cluster coordinates and SPM statistics; results were corrected via small-volume correction within an anatomically defined ACC mask but arise from whole-brain voxelwise GLM analyses and are reported for the healthy/control group. The task is social-related and univariate task-evoked effects (informative vs. uninformative feedback interactions) are presented at group level. Thus it meets the review’s inclusion criteria (social fMRI, healthy adults, group-level univariate voxelwise results).

The study is an fMRI experiment in healthy adults investigating dynamic facial-expression perception (social communication) and meets sample and task criteria. However, all reported statistical inferences appear to rely on ROI-based analyses and small-volume corrections (SVC) for a priori regions; the Methods and Results describe ROI/SVC analyses and report corrected activations within those masks. The paper does not clearly report an unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map or whole-brain results (e.g., whole-brain cluster-corrected contrasts or tables of whole-brain coordinates) for the healthy group. Because the review’s inclusion criterion requires at least one whole-brain, univariate, group-level task activation map, this manuscript fails that requirement and must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task used event-related fMRI during a social-related face memory/recognition task (perception/understanding of others). Sample comprised healthy adult participants (N=18; ages 19–36). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects contrasts, cluster correction) with peak coordinates and figures for activations (e.g., right precentral and cingulate gyri), which are generalizable to the healthy group. The study is empirical and reports original task-evoked BOLD results for the healthy participants. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and results are not limited to a special clinical subgroup). Therefore it should be included in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (final N=43, males aged within 17–65) that examines social processing (preconscious processing of fearful eye whites). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (exploratory whole-brain results are presented with coordinates and cluster statistics) in addition to ROI analyses. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not a review, and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using a social cognition task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=28, age-matched). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise group-level statistical results with coordinate tables and contrasts involving the healthy/control group (e.g., Healthy controls > Huntington's disease; control subgroup contrasts reported in Table 3 and supporting information). Results are task-evoked and reported at group level, generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adult participants.

This is an fMRI study of social-cognitive processing in healthy adult participants (n=74). The task probes social constructs (neutral face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (one-sample t-tests and task contrasts) with FWE-corrected results and figures/tables of activation (e.g., linear increase across conditions in social-brain regions), clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Participants are healthy adults without psychiatric history. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria and does not trigger any exclusion criteria (whole-brain results are present; not ROI-only; task-based, not resting-state).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (scanned sample N=38, ages 19–31). The task is social/affiliative (speed-dating; learning about romantic interest/rejection), clearly addressing social processing constructs (perception/understanding of others, affiliation/attachment). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation contrasts and tables of peak coordinates (e.g., main effects and multiple contrasts with whole-brain FWE correction), generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, no clinical-only sample). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of face perception that explicitly probes social-communication-relevant, changeable aspects of faces (gaze direction, expression, lip movement). Participants were healthy adults (n=8, ages within typical adult range). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (Z statistic images, Talairach coordinates, and a table of peak coordinates for face- and non-face-selective regions), not ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Thus it satisfies the inclusion criteria for an fMRI healthy-adult whole-brain task activation map addressing social-related processing.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (observers watching violent dyadic interactions) in healthy adults (15 male participants, N=14 after motion exclusion; age 23.6±4.1). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., all conditions vs baseline; focus on aggressor vs focus on victim) with statistical maps, coordinate tables and figures—i.e., not restricted to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, non-healthy sample) are violated, so the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (empathic accuracy/empathy) in healthy adults (final fMRI sample N=34, ages 20–30). The task is a social-related, naturalistic Empathic Accuracy Task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (emotional>neutral contrasts, parametric modulation by EA, time-series correlations with intensity ratings) with TFCE FWE-corrected results and peak coordinates/tables, clearly from the healthy/control group. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only approaches. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This study includes a healthy adult control group (H; n=18, ages within 17–65) and uses task-based fMRI during a social cognition task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes). The authors report voxelwise, whole-brain second-level analyses: single-group one-sample t tests were run separately for all five groups (including the healthy control group), and results are presented with cluster-level FWE correction and tables/figures of activation peaks. Therefore it provides an univariate, group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group and is generalizable to healthy adults, meeting all inclusion criteria.

This paper reports an fMRI study (Study 2) that used a social-cognition task (passive viewing of sexualized vs. clothed male and female targets — perception/understanding of others) in a healthy adult sample (21 right-handed heterosexual male undergraduates; mean age ~21). The authors report group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (4×21 ANOVA; voxelwise p<.001 with AlphaSim cluster correction) and provide tables/figures of task-evoked activations and contrasts (e.g., deviant-cell contrast and correlations with hostile sexism). Results are clearly from the healthy adult group and generalizable to that population. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample, or non-empirical) are violated.

Although the study uses task fMRI with a social closeness paradigm in healthy participants, it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map for the healthy adult group. fMRI results are reported using predefined ROIs and extracted beta weights (and correlations), and inferences are based on ROI/SVC analyses rather than an unmasked whole-brain task contrast generalizable to healthy adults. In addition, the sample mixes adolescents (12–18) and adults (19–30) and the paper does not present separate whole-brain results limited to an adult-only subgroup. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps and should be excluded.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=17, ages 20–34) that directly investigates social communication (gaze following and finger pointing). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (gaze-following vs baseline; finger-pointing vs baseline) with statistical thresholds and cluster reporting, including figures and coordinate information; subtraction and conjunction analyses are also reported. While an ROI analysis is included, whole-brain results are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, participants are within 17–65, empirical fMRI data are provided). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for this meta-analysis of fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of theory-of-mind (social cognition) in healthy adults (N=13; ages 22–38). The task explicitly probes social processes (cooperation, deception, belief attribution). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate analyses (exploratory whole-brain ToM vs non-ToM; direct contrasts between conditions) with reported activation clusters and peak coordinates, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Participants are within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported. Although ROI analyses are also used, they stem from an initial whole-brain group contrast, so inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of theory-of-mind/social cognition in healthy adults (N=24; mean age 25.7), using task-based fMRI. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain contrasts (e.g., social>non-social during Background; unexpected>expected during Outcome) with peak coordinates and cluster-level FWE correction (voxel-wise P<0.001, cluster-wise P<0.05) in Tables 2–3. Results for the healthy adult sample are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain group-level task activations reported). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (initial N=28, final neuroimaging N=20; ages 18–55) using an imitation/observation of emotional faces paradigm—clearly a social-related task (perception/understanding of others, empathy). The paper reports whole-brain analyses: a task PLS and a confirmatory SPM8 GLM with voxelwise spatial maps and thresholding; results are presented as voxel patterns/coordinates and described at group level for healthy participants. It is empirical, within the eligible age range, and does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (impression updating/perception and understanding of others) in healthy adults (N=21, ages 18–31). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and ANOVA results (e.g., L2>F3, interaction effects), corrected for multiple comparisons with cluster thresholds and voxel-wise p-values, and provides tables of peak coordinates and figures—satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported. The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, nor is it non-empirical. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=18; age 18–44). The task probes social cognition (prediction of others’ behavior, theory-of-mind and deontic reasoning). Group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses are reported (flexible factorial second-level models, cluster- and voxel-wise corrected results) with tables of coordinates and figures. Results for the healthy/control sample are presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not between-groups-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore the article satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (processing of others’ pupillary signals/eye-region stimuli) in healthy adults (N=14, mean age 22). The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others). Group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses are reported (main effect of viewing eye stimuli reported at whole-brain corrected cluster threshold p<.05; effects of pupil-size change and feedback interactions reported with voxelwise statistics and peak coordinates and ROI analyses). Results are presented as whole-brain statistical maps and coordinates, clearly from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (n=18) and reports whole-brain between-group contrasts (controls > ASC) and pooled-subject whole-brain maps, it does NOT report an unambiguous, unmasked group-level whole-brain task activation map explicitly for the healthy/control group alone. Key reported healthy-group results are presented as between-group contrasts and ROI analyses; within-group effects for controls are described mainly in ROI analyses rather than as whole-brain voxelwise maps. Per the review’s criteria, a standalone healthy-group whole-brain task activation map (voxelwise) is required. Therefore the study does not meet the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.

This is an fMRI study of self-face recognition (Perception and Understanding of Self), a social-related construct. Participants were healthy adults (reported 16 analyzed subjects, ages 19–24), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses: random-effects contrasts with reported significant clusters (e.g., MPFC, PCC, precuneus) and MNI coordinates and thresholding (voxelwise P<0.001, cluster-level P<0.05 FWE), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although ROI analyses (FFA/OFA) are included, whole-brain results are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and is empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20, ages 20–34) that examines neural responses during action observation and execution linked to the mirror system, a process directly relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ and social cognition. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (conjunctions and contrasts) thresholded and corrected for multiple comparisons, and provides peak coordinates in tables (Table 1) and figures. The healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked maps are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and does not violate exclusion criteria. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task: functional MRI during a social interaction (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) probing cooperation/defection (social-affiliation/decision-making). (2) Sample: healthy adult participants (N=30, mean age 21.2, 17–65 range satisfied). (3) Whole-brain evidence: the paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain random-effects and fixed-effects analyses, voxelwise contrasts (e.g., choice C vs D, outcome contrasts CC, CD, etc.), with tables of coordinates and whole-brain voxelwise correlation maps. (4) Not excluded: results are not ROI-only, not limited to clinical groups, and present generalizable healthy-group task activations. Therefore include.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (virtual handshake provoking social acceptance vs. rejection). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=16, mean age 27.4) reported separately from the schizophrenia group. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain within-group contrasts for the healthy/control group (refusal > acceptance) with brain regions and statistics described (right pSTS, thalamus; tables/figures reported and corrected clusters described). The task probes social interaction/mentalizing (Perception and Understanding of Others). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and includes empirical original fMRI data in healthy adults within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults. The sample includes 44 healthy right-handed adults aged 21–60 (within 17–65). The experiment manipulated social judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) versus emotional (happiness) and cognitive (age) judgments on vocal stimuli. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and conjunctions (MNI coordinates, cluster- and FWE-corrected results) assigning activations to cytoarchitectonic areas. Results for the healthy group are reported and generalizable; the study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study reports task-based fMRI during a social face-processing task (Thatcher Illusion) targeting social/emotional processing and attention to eyes (perception/understanding of others). It includes a healthy adult control group (NT; n=18 analyzed, ages within 17–65) with results reported separately. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts for the NT group (within-group upright vs. inverted contrasts; whole-brain thresholding and statistical maps are described and visualized), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. It is empirical, uses fMRI, and does not violate any exclusion criteria (ROIs reported but whole-brain results are also provided). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (gaze perception/ToM). It includes a healthy adult control group (typical male participants) and reports within-group task contrasts for controls (e.g., controls: direct gaze > averted gaze) with coordinates and statistical results. Whole-brain voxelwise contrasts are referenced (faces vs. null was FWE-corrected at the whole-brain level and used to define visual/motor ROIs), and results are presented as group-level univariate contrasts (tables/figures) rather than only seed/ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) healthy adult sample with separable control-group results, and (3) group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked results reported. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical) apply. Confident inclusion for the meta-analysis.

Although this task fMRI study includes healthy adult participants (ages up to 40) and reports whole-brain task activation maps, all reported group-level whole-brain analyses are for the combined sample spanning ages 7–40. The paper does not present a separate group-level, univariate whole-brain activation map or contrast restricted to adults (age 17–65) that is generalizable to a healthy adult population. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group with reported whole-brain task-evoked results.

Although the study used task fMRI of social (Theory of Mind/intentional causality) processing in healthy adult controls (21 controls, age range appropriate), the paper does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group. Analyses are based on group independent component analysis (ICA) and component-based connectivity maps derived across the combined sample (n=36), with between-group (ASD vs control) contrasts reported. ICA-derived component maps and between-group connectivity differences do not meet the inclusion requirement of an univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map from the healthy group. Therefore it fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion.

This is an fMRI study of social communicative processing (recognition of communicative intentions from prosody) in healthy adults (n=22, mean age 27). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (CLEAR > AMBIGUOUS and AMBIGUOUS > CLEAR) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and describes activations across widespread cortical and subcortical regions. Whole-brain results are presented and clearly attributable to the healthy adult sample. Although the study also includes PPI connectivity analyses, it additionally provides the required task-evoked, voxelwise whole-brain activation maps; it is not ROI-only, not resting-state only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (racial in‑group/out‑group facial emotion perception) using a task (passive viewing of faces), addressing social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Sample consists of healthy adult participants (n=26 analyzed; mean age ~21). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (2×2 ANOVA and interaction contrasts), with corrected cluster thresholds and tables of activation coordinates (e.g., Table 1, Supporting Information). Whole-brain results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This fMRI study used a well-established social task (Cyberball social exclusion). It included a healthy adult control group (HC; n=28 female adults) and reports whole-brain, voxelwise within-group results for the healthy controls (main effect of condition in left anterior insula; voxelwise FWE-corrected p<0.05, k≥10). The task probes social-related processing (social exclusion/belonging), and results for the healthy group are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. Although ages are not explicitly listed in the excerpt, participants are described as adult females and recruitment/ethical procedures imply an adult sample. Therefore it meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult group, whole-brain healthy-group task activation reported).

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (recognition of personally familiar vs. famous/unfamiliar faces—perception/understanding of others; social/attachment-related processes). Sample comprises healthy adults (N=24 analyzed; ages 19–31), meeting the age and health criteria. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked univariate analyses (random-effects one-sample t tests; contrasts such as P1-Cp1, P1-F1) with statistical maps, coordinate tables, and figures; results are reported for the healthy control group and are generalizable. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or resting-state analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of implicit social-emotional processing (gender identification of angry and happy faces vs. neutral shapes), which falls squarely within social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Sample: 30 healthy adults (mean age 24.2, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked analyses (random-effects full-factorial ANOVA, whole-brain and ROI results, coordinates/tables, FWE-corrected results and contrasts such as FAC-angry > neutral), not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. Healthy-group whole-brain contrasts are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although this fMRI study includes a healthy control group performing a social (attribution) task, the paper primarily reports between-group (patient vs control) contrast results. While mean % signal changes for the control group are provided at clusters identified by the between-group contrasts, the article does not present an unmasked, whole‑brain, group-level task activation map (e.g., main effect or within-group voxelwise contrast) clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. This fails the review’s requirement for a standalone whole‑brain healthy-group task-evoked statistical map. Therefore it should be excluded.

The study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants during a social impression-formation task, but the manuscript’s reported neuroimaging results are focused on multivariate PLS analyses. The paper does not present any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps or coordinate tables for the healthy sample within this manuscript (it only references a separate/unpublished univariate analysis). Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (maternal perception of own child’s facial emotions — affiliation/attachment and social communication). The sample includes a healthy adult control group (CON; N=26 mothers, adults within typical adult age range) reported separately. The paper presents group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (within-group and between-group contrasts), with whole-brain FWE-corrected activations and coordinates for CON (e.g., familiarity effect in medial frontal gyrus) rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Although a clinical/ELM group is included, healthy-control whole-brain activation maps are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions), conducted in healthy adult participants (N=24, mean age 26). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., bimodal > unimodal fearful and interaction analyses) with FWE-corrected results and MNI coordinates; independent localizers and whole-brain maps/tables are provided. The healthy adult group results are reported and generalizable to the healthy population. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of 23 healthy adult male participants (mean ages 20–22) using a social, self-relevant task (recall of emotionally charged basketball plays by rival fans) tapping social-cognitive constructs (self-referential processing, mentalizing, social context). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (SPM5 random-effects, voxelwise maps, p=0.001 threshold) with tables/figures of activations (MTL, mPFC, TPJ, etc.). It is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and results are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (American and Korean samples; ages ~20–22) investigating persuasion, a social-cognition/mentalizing task (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise contrasts (persuasive vs. unpersuasive) with tables of coordinates and thresholding (p<.001 uncorrected) and conjunction and between-group analyses. Although ROIs were used in Study 3, whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps are clearly reported for Studies 1–3. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants are within 17–65, and data are empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=15 males, mean age 26.6) that explicitly examines social-related processing (animacy perception, mentalizing, social neural network). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses with voxelwise and cluster-level thresholds, and provides coordinates and tables of activation peaks for multiple contrasts (parametric modulation by subjective animacy and movement patterns). The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others via animated interactions). Results for the healthy adult group are reported clearly and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and participants are within the 17–65 age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.
