The study is an empirical task-based fMRI investigation of social processing (self vs other processing in romantic relationships). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=42; ages 23–40) meeting the age criterion. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., self positive > neutral, other negative > neutral) and an ANOVA; results are corrected for multiple comparisons (FWE) and presented in tables/figures (whole-brain activations and SVC reported). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI with a social reward paradigm and includes a healthy adult control group (n=17, ages within 17–65), it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group. The reported whole-brain table and figures reflect between-group contrasts (controls > cocaine users) and the primary statistical analyses emphasized SVC/ROI results (vmPFC and lOFC). There is no clear presentation of an independent, univariate whole-brain healthy-group effect (e.g., within-group controls: agree>disagree) that is generalizable to the healthy adult population. Therefore the paper fails the requirement for whole-brain evidence from the healthy group and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (observation of cooperative vs. affective social interactions) in healthy adults (N=27; ages ~24–26). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation analyses (contrasts vs. landscape, direct comparisons, conjunction analyses) with voxelwise statistics (p<0.05 FWE and exploratory p<0.001 uncorrected) and stereotactic coordinates/figures. Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain results are clearly presented and attributable to the healthy adult sample. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants within 17–65, empirical data). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of social-affective processing (compassion/empathy/affiliation) in healthy adult participants (right-handed females, age 18–35). The task is a social-related event-related paradigm (Socio-Affective Video Task) and the paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain task activation results (e.g., HE vs LE contrasts, parametric modulations) with FWE-corrected statistics and coordinate tables. Healthy-group results are reported and generalizable to healthy adults; results are not limited to a special subgroup. The paper also includes longitudinal between-group training contrasts but crucially provides unmasked whole-brain task effects and voxelwise analyses rather than only ROI or connectivity-only findings. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (mental simulation of personally familiar others) in healthy adults (final sample n=23, ages 18–27). The authors conducted whole-brain voxelwise analyses: they ran GLMs and a searchlight RSA across the brain, combined participant maps via group-level t-tests, and report permutation-corrected, threshold-free cluster-enhanced voxelwise maps with peak coordinates and p-values (Table 1; Figures 1–2). These group-level, whole-brain voxelwise statistical maps are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and reports original task-evoked fMRI data in a healthy adult sample, so it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

The paper reports original fMRI experiments (three experiments) using dynamic and static facial expression tasks—clearly social perception/understanding of others. Samples are healthy adult participants (mean ages ~25; sample sizes reported). Group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses and voxelwise contrasts (dynamic > static, task > baseline) are reported with thresholding and cluster correction; coordinates and tables of results are provided. The study therefore provides univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps for healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and not a non-empirical paper. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study used resting-state fMRI and graph-theory (global efficiency, seed-to-seed connectivity) rather than a task-based, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked fMRI paradigm. Theory of mind was assessed behaviorally outside the scanner (Short Story Task); no healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps (voxelwise task contrasts or within-group activation maps) are reported. Additionally, the sample is adolescent/young (ages 12–24) and not clearly limited to the healthy adult range 17–65 or analyzed as a separate adult healthy subgroup. Therefore it does not meet the requirement for a task-evoked whole-brain healthy adult activation map and is excluded.

Although the study uses fMRI with a social-related face-processing task and includes healthy adult participants, it does not clearly report a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical map that is explicitly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The primary whole-brain analyses were conducted on a combined sample of controls and psychiatric patients (with subsequent checks showing diagnosis had little effect), and the independent replication used an anatomical ROI approach rather than a whole-brain healthy-group map. Per the review’s inclusion rule requiring healthy-group whole-brain results reported separately, this criterion is not met.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI and includes a typically developing control (TDC) group, the sample spans ages 12–31 (mixing minors and adults) and the analyses focus on developmental trajectories and group × age interactions. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from a healthy adult (ages 17–65) subgroup that is generalizable to the healthy adult population. Reported results emphasize interactions and between-group differences and use ROI small-volume corrections; subgroup analyses (e.g., TDC adults) are limited/ exploratory and do not provide a whole-brain healthy-adult task map meeting the review’s inclusion requirements. Therefore it fails the requirement for a clearly reported whole-brain healthy adult group-level task activation map and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing: tasks explicitly probe self-related and social (mentalizing/sharing) processes while participants view article headlines/abstracts. Sample consists of healthy adults (study 1 n≈41, study 2 n≈39; ages 18–24). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task analyses (main text and SI) including whole-brain maps and tables of clusters associated with population-level virality ranks, with multiple-comparison corrections (cluster and nonparametric permutation/FDR). Results are not ROI-only and are reported for the healthy participant groups. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (face-to-face joint attention). It includes healthy adult control groups (age range 18–35; matched control n≈13 and independent ROI control n=22) with results reported separately from the ASD group. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts for the neurotypical/control groups (e.g., RJA>SA, IJA>SA) with tables of coordinates and thresholded maps described in the text and figures. The healthy-group results are generalizable to healthy adults and not limited to a narrow subgroup. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adults reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study does use task fMRI and reports whole-brain activation maps, but it does not meet key inclusion criteria for this meta-analysis: (1) Task domain — the fMRI task is a non-social visual attention/divided-attention paradigm, not a social-related task (e.g., perception/understanding of others, social communication, affiliation/attachment). (2) Sample — participants are boys/children and adolescents (ages ~10–16), not healthy adults aged 17–65; although a ‘control’ group is reported, they are minors and thus not generalizable to healthy adults. While clinical groups (ASC) and unaffected siblings are included and whole-brain results are shown, these do not rescue the study because the healthy/control sample is outside the specified adult age range and the task is non-social. Therefore the study should be excluded.

Study used task-based fMRI during a social-related face-processing task (gender discrimination of emotional faces) in healthy adult participants (two genotype groups; screened for psychiatric disorders). The paper reports group-level univariate fMRI results for the healthy sample (main effects and contrasts; whole-brain results and coordinate tables/figures, Supplementary Table S3), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the adult age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of action perception/understanding (mirror system) — a social-cognitive process fitting “Perception and Understanding of Others.” Participants include healthy adult groups (14 sighted, 8 blind; mean ages 32 and 44, within 17–65) with results reported separately. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., familiar action sounds vs environmental sounds; motor pantomime vs rest), with correction for multiple comparisons and cluster-size thresholds, and presents statistical maps and coordinate-based results. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state, and provides healthy-group whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social decision-making (control aversion to another person) in healthy adult participants (n=51, mean age 22). The task probes social cognition/perception of others and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., decisions controlled > free) with cluster-level FWE correction and peak MNI coordinates (right/left IPL, dlPFC, etc.). Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, the paper also provides conventional whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and accompanying statistics generalizable to a healthy adult sample. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample within 17–65, and whole-brain group-level univariate results).

This is an event-related fMRI study of affective speech comprehension in healthy adults (N=51, ages 18–53). The task probes social-related processing (perception/understanding of others’ emotions via sentence content and prosody), fitting the review’s constructs. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (EMO vs GRAM) with statistical maps and peak coordinates (FWE-corrected results), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Healthy adult data are reported separately and generalizable to the target population. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or resting-state-only (although connectivity analyses are included, whole-brain activation maps are primary). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/interpretation of social actions) in healthy adult participants (two experiments, N=20 each; ages 20–32). The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses: searchlight RSA results with corrected clusters and coordinates are reported (Tables 2–3 and figures), and univariate baseline contrasts (actions vs. baseline) and univariate analyses are described (Supplementary Figs. 11–12 and univariate regression analyses). Results for healthy/control participants are reported at the group level and provide whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps/coordinates. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (task-based fMRI in healthy adults, and group-level whole-brain results reported).

This is an fMRI task study of socially-induced emotion regulation (psychotherapist video instructions) probing social-cognitive processes (attachment, social regulation) in healthy adult participants (female sample age 22–32). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Social-Reg > Social-Look) with cluster-wise FWE correction and tables of peak coordinates. It is empirical, not ROI-only, not limited to connectivity or resting-state-only results, and reports healthy-group task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of empathy (social-related emotional perspective taking) in healthy adult participants (n=26, ages ~24, right-handed), satisfying the sample criterion (17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects univariate contrasts (SELF vs baseline; OTHER vs baseline) with FWE-corrected results and tables of peak coordinates, and additional whole-brain SPM maps and ROI SVC—fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses are clearly presented for the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. The manuscript is empirical original fMRI work (NeuroImage 2008) and does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, not limited to between-group contrasts only). Therefore it should be included.

This fMRI study (Ebisch et al., 2014) investigates anticipatory sensorimotor processing during active interpersonal touch, a clearly social-related task (affiliation/ social interaction). Sample: 16 healthy adults (ages 20–34), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxel-wise whole-brain univariate task contrasts (interaction and main-effect contrasts), cluster-level correction, and tables of coordinates (Table 1), as well as conjunction and tactile-localizer analyses. Results are presented for the healthy/control group and are not ROI-only, resting-state, or between-group-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

While the study uses fMRI in healthy adult control participants (age 27.5 mean) during an emotion/socially-relevant task (IAPS pictures, including social content), it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The paper reports a pooled main effect across all subjects and reports between-group contrasts (siblings vs controls) and ROI analyses, but I could not find a standalone whole-brain within-group (healthy controls) task-evoked statistical map or coordinates clearly attributed to the healthy/control group alone. This violates the inclusion criterion requiring a healthy-group whole-brain univariate task map. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social/affiliation processing (mother–infant attachment) in healthy adult participants (N=23 mothers, ages 22–37). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain GLM contrasts (own infant > unfamiliar infant) with whole-brain statistical maps and tables of activated regions, not limited to ROI-only analyses. Healthy-group results are reported and generalizable to healthy adults; sample falls within the 17–65 age range. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of face perception/recognition in healthy adults (ages within range) and addresses a social-related construct (perception/understanding of others), the paper’s imaging results are presented as ROI-based MVPA and representational similarity analyses. The manuscript does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (e.g., a whole-brain faces>baseline or similar contrast with coordinates or images) for the healthy/control group; instead ROIs were defined using an independent localizer (from a different sample) and analyses focus on ROI and visual-field masks. Because the review’s inclusion criteria require at least one clearly reported group-level univariate whole-brain task activation map from the healthy group, this study does not meet the ‘whole-brain evidence’ criterion and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind/emotion/pain) in healthy adults (N=46 females, ages 18–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., B>Ph, E>Ph, Pa>Ph) with tables of coordinates and cluster-level correction, and describes these results across scenarios and judgment epochs. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes healthy adult participants within the 17–65 range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (joint attention) in healthy adults (final sample N=13, mean age ~24.9, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., RJA - RJAc, IJA - IJAc), conjunction and direct contrasts, with tables of coordinates and FDR-corrected thresholding—i.e., whole-brain voxelwise results for the healthy/control group. It is empirical task fMRI (not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only) and the results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (emotional vocalizations) in healthy adults (N=22; ages 19–36). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrast (voice localizer: [vocal > non-vocal]) with cluster-level correction and MNI coordinates used to define the TVA, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Main experiment results are reported at the group level with coordinates and corrected statistics. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are presented. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=98; mean age 20.7) that investigates social-related processing (self vs. others, closeness/similarity). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., self > Bush; friends > strangers) with whole-brain maps and region coordinates, and describes preprocessing and GLM analyses. Results are reported for the healthy sample and are generalizable to healthy adults within the 17–65 range. The study is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and it provides whole-brain activation maps/contrasts clearly identified for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study using a multiround trust game (social interaction) that includes a healthy adult control group (HC, n=21; ages 18–47). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses and displays group-level task activation maps for benevolence and malevolence for the healthy control group (voxelwise and cluster-level PFWE thresholds are provided). Results include within-group maps and whole-brain ANOVAs and regressions; findings for the HC group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or lack of healthy-group whole-brain task maps) are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (heterosexual men, age 22–50). The task probes social-related constructs (romantic/affiliation and sexual stimuli), and analyses report group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., sexual>neutral, romantic>neutral, romantic>sexual) using whole-head FSL analyses with cluster correction. Results are presented as figures and tables of activation, and contrasts are clearly identified for the healthy/control groups. The paper is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports task-based fMRI in 51 healthy adult participants (mean age 28.5) using masked emotional face stimuli—directly addressing social/attachment-related processing (affiliation/attachment). The authors report group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (one-sample t-tests for masked sad vs neutral and masked happy vs neutral) with tables of significant activations (coordinates, cluster sizes) and figures; results include main effects and regression analyses within the healthy sample. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only approaches, and healthy-group univariate task activation maps are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this is an fMRI study of social perception (trustworthiness/fear appraisal) and includes a healthy adult control group, the paper does not report a clearly identified, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. Results are reported as combined participant maps, ROI analyses for controls, and between-group contrasts (BPD vs. controls). The healthy-group results that are reported are ROI-based (amygdala mask) rather than whole-brain voxelwise maps clearly attributed to the healthy group. Because the review requires at least one group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked map for the healthy/control group, this study does not meet the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

The study reports task-based fMRI of social self-processing (direct, reflected evaluations) — a social-related construct (Perception/Understanding of Self). It includes a healthy adult group (N=19; ages 22–31). Whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses were performed (SPM8; group-level repeated-measures ANOVA with Monte Carlo/AlphaSim cluster correction; voxel-wise p<0.005, k=64), and the manuscript and supplementary materials report group-level results and separate analyses for adult and adolescent neural recruitment (tables/figures referenced). Thus the paper provides whole-brain, task-evoked univariate maps attributable to a healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, contains healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=25, mean age ~26) that examines socio-emotional processing using naturalistic film scenes. The experiment reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (thresholds and cluster-corrected results are given; multiple tables/figures with coordinates and maps are provided) linking activity in social-cognition regions (STS, IPL, mPFC, amygdala, etc.) to subjective conflict and valence prioritization. Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, the paper also provides univariate whole-brain task effects for the healthy sample. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group results) and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=15 after exclusion; ages 20–28) examining detection of visuo-motor and visuo-proprioceptive synchrony (self vs. non-self movement), a construct that maps onto ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ (ownership). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (Aa-As, Pa-Ps) with statistical parametric maps and a table of peak coordinates (Table 1) and figures. The healthy-control group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=21 males, age 21–39), uses a social-related task (negative vs positive social feedback), reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (negative social feedback > positive social feedback) with random-effects analysis, corrected voxelwise thresholds, tables/figures with peak coordinates. Not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (eye-gaze perception) in a sample of healthy adults (N=18; ages 18–30). The paper reports second-level, within-group univariate whole-brain analyses (SPM-t maps) assessing contrasts and correlations with AQ, with whole-brain FDR-corrected results and coordinate tables (i.e., voxelwise, group-level task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to the healthy group). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and not limited to between-group contrasts. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of emotion perception from dynamic avatars (social perception / perception and understanding of others) using an explicit emotion-classification task. Sample: healthy adult participants (N=19, mean age 28±4.5; age range within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate GLM contrasts (e.g., perceived emotional vs. neutral gait), with multi-subject activation maps, Monte Carlo cluster correction, and ROI analyses; whole-brain statistical maps and contrasts are presented in figures and described in the text. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI/connectivity or non-healthy sample) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion requirements for the meta-analysis.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=21) during episodic retrieval of socially encoded life events (oral social interactions), which qualifies as social-related processing (self and social interaction). The sample consists of healthy adults. Group-level, univariate whole-brain task activations are reported (episodic retrieval network activations; P < .05 corrected), and task-evoked contrasts are clearly described; hippocampal findings used small-volume correction but whole-brain retrieval activations are reported. The design is empirical fMRI (task), not ROI-only, resting-state, or connectivity-only, and results are presented for the healthy group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

Although the study uses task fMRI of social rejection (Cyberball) and includes a healthy adult group (n=16, age 23.9–38.8), the paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map that is clearly identified as coming from the healthy adult group alone. Reported whole-brain, cluster-corrected results are for the combined sample (adolescents + adults). Adult-specific findings are limited to post-hoc t-tests and a small-volume-corrected interaction in right vlPFC (SVC) and uncorrected within-group tests, rather than a whole-brain, corrected adult-group contrast or coordinate table. Therefore it fails the requirement for a healthy-adult whole-brain, univariate task-evoked map (inclusion criterion 3). All other exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age outside range) are not the issue; the lack of adult-specific whole-brain results mandates exclusion.

This study reports task-based fMRI during a social perception task (emotional face processing of anger and fear), involving healthy adult participants. The full text describes group-level neural activity in face- and emotion-processing regions (amygdala, fusiform, insula) and discusses task-evoked whole-brain effects; these constitute univariate, voxelwise, group-level results generalizable to healthy adults. Although functional coupling analyses are also reported, the paper clearly provides whole-brain task activation findings rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participant age range and healthy-group analyses are implicit in the methods and results focusing on nonclinical adult samples. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although the study includes a social-related fMRI task (facial expression discrimination) and a healthy adult control group (age range appropriate), it does not report a whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation map for the healthy/control group. The paper presents task results primarily as between-group contrasts (patients > controls amygdala hyperactivation) and does not provide an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect (coordinates/figure/tables) that are generalizable to healthy adults. Per the review inclusion rules, absence of a healthy-group whole-brain task map requires exclusion.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=16, ages 20–31) that investigates cross-modal person recognition (voice–face), a social perception task relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. Group-level, voxelwise second-level analyses were performed and reported with MNI coordinates for task contrasts and connectivity; results are described for the healthy participant group and are generalizable to healthy adults. Although many results are reported with ROI-based correction, the manuscript describes whole-brain voxelwise analysis procedures and provides group-level univariate task contrasts and peak coordinates. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This paper reports an fMRI task probing social/attachment processing (imagery sentence completion about ‘My mother’/‘My father’). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=15) alongside patients, with participants described as adults. The authors report within-group, voxelwise whole-brain task activations for the healthy/control group (one-sample t-tests; significant clusters and MNI coordinates presented in Table 2, precuneus etc.), satisfying the requirement for univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps. The study is empirical fMRI work of social processing in healthy adults, and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

The study used task fMRI with a social-related paradigm (implicit fearful vs neutral faces) and included a healthy control group, but the paper does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control participants. The main results focus on PPI effective connectivity and between-group connectivity differences (patient vs control). No unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect (e.g., control group activation map or within-group contrast tables/figures) is presented in this manuscript (the text refers to earlier work for activation details). Because it reports only seed-based effective connectivity and between-group contrasts without a healthy-group whole-brain activation, it fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion and meets the exclusion criterion for connectivity-only studies.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=18, females, age 19–28) investigating social communication (perceived friend vs computer). The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., friend > computer) with thresholded statistical parametric maps and a table of significant whole-brain clusters (dmPFC, precuneus, TPJ, temporal poles). Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches; whole-brain voxelwise results are clearly described and generalized to the healthy sample. The task probes social-related processing (mentalizing/communication) and meets the age and sample criteria. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants (nulliparous women, ages 19–29) performing social-related tasks (perception of infant emotional cries and faces; relevant to social communication/perception of others/affiliation). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., high- vs low-distress cries; happy vs neutral faces) with voxelwise results, cluster correction, coordinates, and images generalizable to the healthy adult sample. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is a methods/functional-parcellation study using resting-state fMRI in 20 healthy adults and meta-analytic coactivation (MACM) via the BrainMap database. It does not report original task-evoked, group-level whole-brain fMRI activation maps from the authors' healthy sample for a social-related task. Although the paper uses BrainMap to infer associations (including social cognition) via ALE and functional characterization, these are meta-analytic coactivation results rather than within-study univariate task activation maps. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring an original whole-brain task-evoked statistical map from healthy adults participating in a social-related fMRI task.

This study reports task-based fMRI in a sample of aMCI patients and healthy aging controls, but the reported results focus on ROI-based and seed/voxel-level functional connectivity and network analyses (correlation matrices, seed-based connectivity maps, conjunctions). It does not provide a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map for the healthy/control group (e.g., task>baseline or within-group activation contrasts). Per the review’s exclusion criteria, studies that report only seed-based or connectivity analyses without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation are ineligible. Additionally, participants are described as an aging/aMCI sample (likely older than 65), so the healthy group may fall outside the 17–65 age range, further reducing applicability.

fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind/implicit belief processing) in healthy adults (final N=22; mean age 24.4 within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain random-effects GLM results from an explicit general-belief localizer contrast (false-belief vs false-photograph) at q(FDR)<0.05 with peak Talairach coordinates and a whole-brain statistical map (Fig.2A and text). Although some analyses used ROIs, the study includes clearly reported whole-brain, task-evoked healthy-group results that are generalizable to healthy adults, satisfying inclusion criteria.

The study includes a healthy adult control group (n=25, mean age ~23), uses task-based fMRI during social-related processing (rapid fearful face perception), and reports group-level univariate activation results for the control group. Within-group control activations are provided (e.g., bilateral fusiform, right amygdala, pulvinar, superior colliculi) in Table 2 and Supplementary materials, and whole-brain analyses are described in the supplement. Although ROIs were used, whole-brain mixed-effects analyses (FLAME) and coordinate clusters for the healthy/control group are reported, satisfying the requirement for an univariate whole-brain task-evoked map generalizable to healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of gesture planning/execution—a social communication task (pantomime gestures) relevant to Social Communication. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=25) with results reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task-evoked analyses (within-group effects and contrasts for controls) with explicit thresholds (P≤.001) and cluster criteria; within-group/control maps/results are described in the main text and supplementary materials. The study is empirical and not ROI-, connectivity-only, or resting-state-only. Although a patient group is included, healthy-control whole-brain task activation is clearly provided and generalizable to healthy adults. Participant ages are not explicitly listed but recruitment sources (staff, students, matched adults) indicate an adult sample within the 17–65 range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants investigating social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking). The task is explicitly social-related, and the paper reports group-level task-evoked whole-brain univariate activations (activation in ventral/dorsal anterior MPFC, posterior dorsal MPFC, and left dorsal MPFC for the interaction), which indicates whole-brain voxelwise contrasts rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participants are healthy adults (university sample), and results are presented as generalizable group-level effects. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy or out-of-range sample, or non-empirical paper) appear to be violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social processes (self/other evaluation and perspective-taking) and includes a healthy adult control group, it does not report an unambiguous whole‑brain, group-level (one-sample) task activation map for the healthy/TD group alone. Reported fMRI results are primarily between-group contrasts (ASD vs TD), combined-group main effects, ROI-based analyses, and seed-based beta-series connectivity results. The paper therefore lacks an unmasked, whole-brain, task-evoked statistical map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group, which is required by the inclusion criteria.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (n=24) and uses task-based fMRI during a social/empathy task, the paper reports only between-group whole-brain contrasts (control > schizophrenia and schizophrenia > control) and derived percent signal change within those between-group clusters. It does not present or report an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical map or within-group main-effect activation map explicitly for the healthy/control group that would be generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it fails the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and must be excluded.

This fMRI study includes a healthy control group of adults (n=28, mean age 21.6) and reports within-group, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts for the healthy group (e.g., self>other and 3PP>1PP activation maps and tables of clusters). The task probes social-related constructs (self-referential processing and perspective-taking), which fit the review’s scope (Perception and Understanding of Self). Whole-brain voxelwise results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented in tables and text. Although recruitment targeted ages 15–35, group means indicate adult participants within the 17–65 range and the study is not limited to underage-only samples. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria: social-related fMRI task, healthy adult group, and whole-brain task activation maps reported.

While the study used task fMRI of social processing (implicit emotional face perception) and included a healthy adult control group, the full text does not clearly report an univariate, whole-brain, within-group statistical map for the healthy/control group (only patient within-group maps and patient-vs-control contrasts are reported in detail). The paper describes some control activations qualitatively but does not provide a clear, generalizable whole-brain control-group task effect (coordinates/tables/figures) that can be used for the meta-analysis. Therefore it fails the requirement for reporting a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and must be excluded.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social processing (emotion recognition with direct/averted gaze), reporting group-level whole-brain results. It includes a healthy younger adult group (17–27 years) within the 17–65 range and presents whole-brain voxelwise findings (PLS-derived maps with peak coordinates and cluster tables) clearly attributed to the healthy participants. Results for younger controls are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-connectivity-only, and provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps/coordinates. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (perception of fearful faces) including a healthy adult control group (N=13; mean age 25.6, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts for the control group (e.g., main effect of faces vs scrambled baseline and linear contrasts of fear intensity) with coordinates and figures, using a random-effects GLM and whole-brain thresholding (p<0.001 uncorrected) and reporting activations (with small-volume corrections for a priori ROIs). Results for the healthy/control group are presented separately from the clinical (HFA/AS) group. Although ROI/SVC procedures were applied to hypothesized social-brain regions, the study provides univariate, whole-brain task activation maps/coordinates for the healthy adults, satisfying inclusion criteria. Therefore it should be included in the meta-analysis.

This fMRI study uses a social-related task (facial emotion discrimination/perception of others) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=12, ages ~24.5). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (within-group contrasts such as sad>neutral shown separately for controls and described in the text and figures) using SPM2 with voxelwise inference and cluster reporting. Healthy-group results are presented (figures and text) and thus satisfy the requirement for an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task activation map. Although the clinical high-risk group is also included, the healthy control group’s whole-brain task effects are reported separately. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: Task is an explicit facial emotion perception fMRI paradigm (social communication/perception of others). Sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=22; mean age 31.7, within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, univariate group-level task activation maps/contrasts for the healthy control group (one-sample t tests for the ‘faces minus animals’ contrast; figures and supplementary tables of activation foci and coordinates are provided). Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related approach-avoidance task with social and nonsocial stimuli in a healthy adult sample (male, mean age 21.35, within 17–65). Group-level task-based neuroimaging analyses were performed (first- and second-level contrasts), and the paper reports task-evoked activation results including whole-brain analyses (supplementary/ exploratory whole-brain results are reported beyond ROI/SVC findings). The study is empirical, not clinical-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and includes healthy-group results generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (task fMRI of social processing; healthy adult sample; group-level whole-brain task results reported).

Although the study includes an fMRI task of social cognition (RMET) and reports whole-brain, group-level task activation maps for the healthy participants, the healthy sample is 20 older adults aged 51–84 (mean 68.4) and is not restricted to the review’s required age range (17–65). The paper does not report a separate healthy subgroup within 17–65. Therefore it violates the age eligibility criterion and must be excluded despite meeting other fMRI and whole-brain reporting requirements.

This paper reports original fMRI data in healthy adult participants (three studies, combined N=59; all participants unique and within adult age range). Each study implemented social-related tasks (person knowledge, famous names, socially relevant words) and appropriate non-social controls. The authors conducted voxelwise, group-level whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM8) reporting contrasts of interest (social > non-social semantics) with cluster- and voxel-level thresholds and provide peak coordinates and whole-brain results in text/tables/figures. Analyses are clearly identified as coming from the healthy control groups. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes whole-brain task activations, healthy adult sample). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of theory-of-mind (a social-cognition task) in healthy adult volunteers (n=109). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrast (ToM>control) with significant main effects (P<0.01 FWE) and provides coordinates/figures/tables of activation; genotype effects are also reported at whole-brain corrected levels. The sample is healthy adults and results for the healthy group are reported and generalizable. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of visual perspective taking/theory-of-mind in healthy adults (n=16, mean age ~22.4). The task is social (self vs other visual perspective judgments). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts with voxelwise results and tables of coordinates (cluster-level FWE correction reported), including multiple contrasts (e.g., Inconsistent Other > Consistent Other) generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and includes a healthy adult sample within the 17–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

While the study uses task fMRI of social/emotional processing and includes healthy adult controls (ages within 17–65), the full text does not clearly report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map that is explicitly identified as coming from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. The manuscript emphasizes PPI (seed-based connectivity) results and between-group comparisons, and indicates that activation details are in the supplementary material but does not present an unmasked/control-only whole-brain task effect in the text. Because the review requires a clearly identified healthy-group whole-brain task map, and this criterion is not met/unambiguously reported, the study must be excluded.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of face perception (socially-relevant stimuli) in healthy young adults, it does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps or coordinate tables for the healthy/control group. Analyses are ROI-based interregional BOLD correlations and structural covariance (25 predefined ROIs) and group-level connectivity/covariance matrices; no unmasked whole-brain activation maps or voxelwise contrasts are presented. This violates the inclusion requirement for whole-brain evidence and matches the exclusion criterion for studies reporting only ROI analyses without whole-brain results.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (27 recruited, 20 analyzed; mean age 24.6), investigating social-communication processes (observation and imitation of social vs non-social gestures). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., IMI > CT; S > NS), cluster-corrected results and tables/coordinates in MNI space, clearly from the healthy/control sample. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only methods. The healthy adult results are reported and generalizable (whole-brain contrasts and coordinates). Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study used fMRI during a social joint-attention task and included a healthy adult control group (80 HCs), it does not report a clear group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group that is generalizable to healthy adults. The paper’s primary analyses focus on ICA-derived cross-brain coupling and between-pair comparisons (permutation tests and group contrasts), and the Results only state absence of group differences in task-related brain activity without providing an unmasked HC within-group whole-brain activation map or coordinates for a HC main-effect contrast in the main text or figures reviewed. Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement for reporting a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and must be excluded.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (matched typically developing males, age range within 17–65) and uses task-evoked fMRI during a social cognition task, it does not report an unmasked, whole‑brain group-level activation map (or coordinates) for the healthy/control group alone. The paper reports between-group contrasts (typically developing > ASD) and regions where ASD shows reduced activity, but does not present a clearly identified, generalizable healthy-group whole‑brain task effect (e.g., one-sample healthy-group maps or coordinates). Per the review’s inclusion criteria, a separate healthy-group whole-brain univariate result is required. Therefore the study must be excluded.
